29953963.review:
Quick Review after owning this for about 6 months - "BUY THIS GAME"

10/10 would turn off crew's oxygen supply to power sheilds again (and the fact you can do this for strategy purposes totally blew me away)

The creative ideas that went into this game astound me:

(some as to not spoil this)

IDEA! - Wanna fix your ship?
- no problem, just shout the engineer to power down the shields so the hull can be repaired!

         - oh wait, He's just the janitor that found the engineer's uniform and has no idea how to do that.. or put out the fires on the ship mid battle.. or the process to turn the shields back on without turning off the power to all the ships many computers.. and weapon systems.. and accidentally ejects the engine in a blind panic while the scientist is yelling at him.. then the pilot loses patience and goes "space nuts" - starts firing his pistol at the glass at the front of the ship while hammering on the distress beacon like he's practicing to survive the Torture Scene in a Metal Gear Solid game.

- Learn the engineer role yourself and restart the game as the engineer - sit with a crew while a new pilot warp into new territories to discover an intergalactic hull eating virus that causes everyone else on the ship to start yelling, "engineer you noob, get the warp core charged now!!!" - tell the captain, "I just can't do it, I don't have the power" - because the captain spent all the money on the giant laser that the weapons specialist was pestering him about last time you docked and forgot the fuel/core charger upgrade... watch with a sense of "I told you so" as the weapon's specialist clutches himself in a corner over the fact he never got to use his big gun he always polished in the creeping realisation that in seconds, his life is over...

--> The most underrated, under played game I have ever enjoyed. The one thing that would make this better is more people playing it and more Dev time.

I hate to say this but.. and I apologise in advance... "I would even be happy if EA bought this team/game" (If it meant a bigger team working on this project continually pumping in content for full price expansions.)

Would happily pay full price for a larger team working on this project as it's genius that's being totally overlooked.

It did to space games what Vampire the Masquerade: bloodlines did for vampire games (Introduced gameplay never before used, set the bar crazy high and then went totally unnoticed and became a cult legend only to be pined over by adoring fans 12 years and counting.. wishing.. just what if.. someone made a game this good again..)

This is game is amazing. I can't put it any other way. The first time playing it is the most fun, and even then, it's still fun trying to faguely cooperate on not dieing with the rest of your crew. I'm mostly going to explain each of the positions main roles, because I can't reveiw right now.

Captain: You are the Captain. You pretty much tell everyone what to do, and preferably help during battles by shooting one of the smaller guns. A bad captain with a fantastic crew could do worse than a good captain with a bad crew. Don't let them down.

Weapon Specialist: As the Weapon Specialist, or Wep Spec for people who can't say more than 1 syllabyll at a time, you fire the ships biggest gun. You also get extra damage resistance later on for when you warp to other ships, or the surface of planets. Keep your aim steady and try not to miss.

Pilot: The Pilot flys the ship. Allign for the next destination, wait for the warp to end, and DEAR GOD THERE IS A ROCK INFRONT OF US WHERE IS THE BREAKS?!?!

Scientist: As a 100% normal Scientist who is not mad, I swear, your job is the run viruses and programs to tilt the dogfight in your favor, be it one that stops the opposition in it's tracks, or a simple boost to your shields, as well as scaning planets for hostiles before beaming down. 

Engineer: Engineer, you have 1 job, see that glowing ball? Do NOT let it overheat. You can also, on Scientists request preferably, refuel the Programs and Viruses by sacraficing a Fuel Cell, but make sure you keep enough to get to the next station. This one can be quite difficult early game, but grows easier as your group gets better Reactors for the ship.

Some people might prefer one over another, but all 5 are needed to keep the ship running smoothly. So, ready for the space adventure of multiple lifetimes, known as "Pulsar: Lost Colony"?

29531137.review:
Очень хороший симулятор космического корабля, разработчикам получилось реализовать большинство функций. Несмотря на то, что игра рассчитана на мультиплеер, играть можно и в одиночку абсолютно свободно, за исключением боя с сильными противниками, тут уже должен быть пилот, оружейник и тот, кто будет бегать и чинить корабль.

Геймплей удобный и несложный, всему можно выучиться буквально за полчаса с умеренным знанием английского. Сначала может показаться, что заданий мало, но если вам нечем заняться, можете помочь людям с сигналом бедствия, или побегать по базе вашей фракции. На базе Колониального Союза есть много людей, которые дают самые разные задания. ИИ ведёт себя немного неадекватно: враги очень прыткие, ловкие и меткие, из-за этого захват корабля в одиночку без перков на здоровье и урон становится трудной задачей. Управление легко заучивается после двух-трёх посещений настроек управления.

Графика, конечно, не на уровне ААА игр, но я не являюсь графонодрочером, да и не нужна здесь графика. Звуковое сопровождение очень хорошее, сразу погружаешься в игру, особенно в наушниках.

Если собрались играть с друзьями - готовьтесь к тому, что играть станет немного легче. Если ваши друзья не играют или если у вас нет друзей - создайте публичную сессию (обязательно сохранитесь) или присоединитесь к другим. Желательно наличие микрофона, т.к. в критических ситуациях ни вам, ни товарищам по команде писать будет некогда. Обязательно знание английского для публичных сессий. Игроки адекватные и вполне могут помочь в любой ситуации. Не так давно собрались в моей сессии пять человек, из которых четыре говорили, очень хорошо сыгрались. Очень редко, но попадаются люди, которые заходят, расстреливают системы твоего корабля и выходят, но это нестрашно: починкопушка всегда под рукой

Лично для меня свою главную задачу - летать на корбале - игра выполнила. Очень доволен проведённым временем. Рекомендую

I backed the kickstarter on this game for a significant chunk of change and have played it on and off ever since it first came into pre alpha. I do not regret my purchase.

Here is my abridged oppinion of the game:
[list]
[*]It is good over all and development is steadily improving the game.
[*]Im a big fan of the artistic style, music, and the teamwork/exploration oriented gameplay.
[*]The community behind the game is also rather friendly and welcoming.
[*]My only big complaint is that there is no ability to make the player-character jump. (at least the last time I checked that is), instead you will require a jetpack which for some reason is only available on one of the ship classes, which limits the exploration you can do if you do not choose said ship.
[*]My other complaint is that Foxxy is no longer to be found anywhere. :c
[*]I keep coming back to this game after leaving it for several months. And every time I do I am pleasantly surprised by the new content.
[*]The crew AI is not very smart, and not easy to command either; however the last time I played they improved significantly and I expect them to get better in the future.
[/list]

Sadly I've yet to have the chance to play this game to the fullest as I've never had all 4 of my friends online and willing at the same time to play with. That one is on me however.

Required perhipherals to play this game properly:
[list]
[*]More friends with the game than I have.
[*]A Discord server or simmilar and associated pehripherals (mics for everyone, etc.)
[/list]

29397722.review:
Итак впечатления. 

Сначала вроде как думаешь - кооп фрилансер на одном корабле. Но потом понимаешь, что игра суть реализация настольных систем про партии на космических кораблях. Взаимодействие партии между собой и тактика прохождения галактики, т.е., последовательность варп-прыжков, тут намного более важны, чем личный скил. Чтобы было понятно - смысл не в пыщ-пыще из орудий, а в отдаче капитаном соответствующего приказа, и выполнении его экипажем. Именно непонятки между экипажем заведут вас в самую ж... интересную игровую ситуацию.

Что сейчас там есть:
Квесты с контрабандой у АОГ. Это пока что самое интересное, что там есть.
Пиратство, абордаж, распил кораблей.
Планеты. Интересность зависит от времени добавления их в игру, а также от наличия ученого и общей прокачки. В принципе, чем больше людей, тем проще лутать и тем меньше пригар от этого.
3 "босса" + инфекция.
Кораблей 7+1 и они даже игромеханически разные и предполагают разные стили игры. После середины игры стилей всего два.
Можно пить водку, закусывая бисквитом и жить с вайфу-ботом в одной каюте.

Чего нет:
Собственно, потерянной колонии.
Лекарства от инфекции.
Возможности нюхать варп-пыль и блекджека. Но я верю.
 
Какие у игры минусы.

Минусы проистекают имхо, из неготовности разрабов оперется на комьюнити. Сами разрабы между тем прокачивают свои скилы, это заметно (плакал от ностальгии по SoF, бегая по поезду). НО:
- *%:? ТУТ ТАК МАЛО?! 
- Локализации нет, что заставляет напрягать мозг не по делу, и соответственно усложняет РП погружение в игру. С управлением как раз сложностей не возникает, ибо все боевые посты абсолютно логично исполнены, для тонкостей есть капитан - пусть он и думает, а вот читать простыни квестов и реплики персонажей не так весело.
- Разрабы не хотят делать ПВП в игре, при этом, игра пока далека от того, чтобы дать челлендж игроку, и блин неизвестно сколько им надо будет еще работать, чтобы космический бой давал вызов, например пока что брутален только древний спутник, и то только из-за ЭМИ-ракет и вирусов.(на нем легкий путь все таки фишка, звезда смерти-стиль).

А какие у тебя есть альтернативы этой игре? Инжи, стармейд, империон. Выбирай между стульев, как говорится... Вместе мы выживем!

29371328.review:
I've played this game since it was a wee lad, about 2 months shy of nothing at all. Even then I was completely mesmerized. I'll state right off that I may be bias as this was the only game me and my brother could play together for several weeks running and I would certianly recommend playing w/ a friend(s) or expect to play online. Thats not to say there isnt an acceptable bot system in the game allowing you to play offline, but it just doesnt quite cut it honestly. This game isnt A+ but it is one of my favorite games. The scope of the gameplay is pretty amazing and with it's replayability factor, your gametime is only limited by your imagination. If you want some polished beautifully designed UI with top of the line graphics this may not be your thing but if you've ever watched Star Trek and wished you could somehow partake, this is about as close as it gets. 
Imagine, you can get your own star ship to roam around the somewhat depressingly doomed galaxy with a crew of your buddies. Take on your foes in adrenalizing firefights, cannons blasting away at your enemy's shield and hull as your reactor begins to heat up, all the while your men blaze away against an enemy boarding action in the lower decks. At the same time the enemy captain opens up comms and demands your immediate surrender. Just before he and his ship blow into a thousand pieces and you get to loot the remains and sell it for personal profit..

29300800.review:
This is a review for Beta 12.2, and the game is most definitely not done yet, though it's quite playable and fun. If you're wondering if you should play it, I would answer "yes, probably later".

A brief list of things not done yet:
Any VR support
A victory condition
Final balance
Most of the science scans
Non-trivial progression (I hope this is intended to be added, but not sure)

There's probably 10-20 hours of gameplay in this thing, unless you like doing the same stuff over and over.

Now for the real review. This is a game about being the crew of one spaceship going about the galaxy doing stuff. It supports up to 5 players, though any role but Captain can be taken over by bots. You're the only player ship; there is no multiplayer except for the rest of your crew. 

There are 5 roles: Captain, Engineer, Scientist, Pilot, Weapons Specialist. The captain basically just sets objectives, controls purchasing, and yells at people. He also can authorize a couple drastic measures, like Emergency Blind Warp. The pilot flies the ship and aligns warps. That's it. The gunner fires the guns. That's also it. The engineer manages power allocation, fixes the ship, charges the warp drive, puts out fires, and reboots the ship, if necessary. The scientist toggles between 2 shield modes, scans other ships and planets for lifeforms, their ship components, and to determine if the environment is safe. They also conduct cyber warfare against enemy ships, and do research.

These are just the default roles; most players can do most things, as they're not locked to a class. Nothing prevents you from wandering over to the engineer's station to recharge your viruses as the scientist, except the fact it's easier to ask him to do it himself. Even the powerful main gun can be fired by anyone taking the right talent (it costs 1 point, and you get 2 per level). Further, manning guns, fighting fires, doing repairs, and going on away missions are all things that are really shared responsibilities. The pilot can't run off and man a gun in the middle of combat (unless he's replaced at the helm by another crew member), but the engineer, scientist, and/or captain could easily decide their talents would be best used in the weapons bay, depending on the particular combat in question.

Captain - This role depends entirely on your own communication skills, and if your crew is a box of awfuls or not. In an experienced crew, you may find yourself with little to do beyond picking the objectives and going on away missions.
Gunner - Sit in a gun, shoot it every time it's charged and you have a clean shot. Also the most easily botted role.
Pilot - As piloting plus gunning is enough to have a game, I feel like this is one of the most engaging roles.
Scientist - Cyber warfare is disappointing, because there's no real way to scale it. You can buff your cyber defenses with firewalls, but your offense starts as good as it ever gets. That means your impact on fights is minimal, and you're better off manning a gun most of the time.
Engineer - Engineers dump coolant, and hope nothing breaks. That's about it.

Lets talk about away missions briefly. Most are bad. You beam down to a mission, you fight somewhere between 0 and 50 enemies, most of whom just charge in to melee you and you shoot them while backpedaling. Then you look around for science items and ship parts. Eventually the scientist gets upgrades to make this procedure a lot easier, in the form of a neat scanner that tells him where stuff is. The actual FPS combat feels like they bought it off the shelf and implemented it as-is. It feels worse than Merchant Marine. That said, there are some handcrafted missions/encounters that just feel awesome. If you ever beam down and find yourself on a train, you're in for a good time.

Finally, I'll talk about pacing a bit. I expect they'll stretch it out a bit as they near release; games are usually a lot easier to progress through in Early Access so you can find bugs and/or the good parts faster. For each kind of ship component, there are roughly 2 viable choices, and 3 or so bad ones. Sometimes less. For instance, there's a jump drive that charges quickly, one with a tiny EM signature making you harder to sense, a slower, longer range one, and a standard one. The answer, of course, is pick the longest range one and then pump up your charge time with talents and jump processors. You can also upgrade your ship by boarding an enemy and taking over. This is awesome, but not too exciting from a progression standpoint. The strongest combat ship is the game is one of the starter ships. You can buy the best cyber warfare programs at the beginning of the game, or start with them. Currently the basic path of the game goes: begin, do a few missions for credits and upgrades, then go grind science for a long time or until you have all the talents you want. Then fight the unique "boss" ships, steal their special parts, and declare victory.

And a bonus pet peeve: something called the infection spreads across the galaxy. You may be able to stop it by fighting, but you definitely can't handle it in any other way. The requirements for fighting it are extremely high. This means that your endgame is a warship or a warship, or having necessarily few choices and opportunities than a warship would.

Overall though, it's an awesome game because you get a persistant universe, and a ship you crew with up to 4 of your closest friends (except that guy in engineering, he's a jerk and he never gives you enough power). The idea is so, so good and the core of the game is so good that in spite of all my whining above, and all the polish the game still needs to reach version 1.0, I highly recommend it. Just maybe not quite yet.

28987830.review:
I'm surprised this game is not more known and popular, it's  pretty much a more complex, first person co-op version of FTL that even allows you to land on planets and space stations where you can even do fps combat.

You and your crew of friends go around exploring the galaxy with your ship, completing various objectives for difrent factions or fighting them which increase or decreases your relationship with the faciton you're interacting. 
You got the captain,pilot,weapons specialist,scientist and engineer all who have rather unique jobs and rols to fill for every situation, especially in combat.
Just like in let's say FTL, things can be going all great and nice and untill suddenly you warp into a new sector with a bunch hostile ships that are far more powerfull then you and kick your ass if you don't quickly do a blind jump.

Engineer manages power usage, shields, cooling, warp jumps, extraction of materials/good from abandoned ships and can even shoot out the power core from the ship before it blows up which can end up stranding you in said sector, making you have to activate a distress call for help. Other classes fill diffrent roles, scientist makes fire walls againts viruses, scans systems,planets,ships, resereaches and upgrades stuff if you bring him material to analyze and the others [Pilot,Captain,Weapons Specialist] are rather self explanatory.

If you ever wished to play a game where you and your friends are a space ship crew, exploring a large galaxy and doing various quests/jobs for difrent factions then you will love this.
Only bad things I'd say is the performance is a bit jumpy and stuttery, but not all that bad really and it's a bit bugy at times with some missions being impossible to complete to due somehing glitching out.

28962798.review:
I spent the first hour running amok in the starting ship. Every screen displays real updates about your ship. Every control panel functions. There is a six-step process to rebooting your ship which involves monster circuit breakers and touch screens nestled behind the warp core.
On my second multiplayer stint, we contacted a smuggler in the back alley of a space station, escaped the clutches of corporate drone gunships and jetpacked through a vast ancient planetary ruin so cold our EVA suit glass frosted over. This is apparently just one mission in a randomized, constantly-evolving galaxy.
The only successful missions I have flown required teamwork. Pilot has to orient the ship so that the weapons officer can see the enemy. Engineer has to juggle power between the engines, weapons, and the power-hungry jump drive. Captain has to order the crew to stop firing phase pistols at viewscreens during critical operations.
Bottom line: this game is packed with detail, takes place in a changing universe, and requires multiplayer cooperation. If your dream is for you and your friends to take a starship and explore the dangers of deep space, this is your game. If that is not your dream, you are lying.

28950547.review:
I enjoyed this game thoroughly. Pilot was my first role (and the perspective this review is based on). I did read the entire manual before starting, though, so I understood the mechanics before starting (took about 30 minutes to read the manual). The physics of the ship are great. The ship drifts, gradually accelerates and reduces speed, and can move in all 8 directions (up, down, left, right, roll right/left, pitch up/down). Sometimes the enemy will shoot you with something huge and will spin the ship out of control - very crazy and hard to recoup from. At one point I hid behind a comet and would come out to give my gunner visual, take some damage, and duck back down before our shield went down. The enemy A.I maneuver in very smart ways. I was impressed.
There are 5 classes: Captain, Pilot, Engineer, Scientists, and Weapons.

Each class can perform the roles of each other and Captains have the option of using A.I. My adventure saw me on a ship with 2 others - a Captain and Engineer for a while. We eventually got a full ship. Many people joined and left. I started playing at 3 am CST and just stopped at 12 pm. These were random people. I did not go into this game with anyone else. I simply joined one of the open ships on the server browser. 2 of the people I adventured with are now on my steam.

Adventuring in the game was seamless and fun. Players use warp drives to go to different star systems. Warping to different star systems sometimes prompts the captain to accept or deny a mission. Accepting a mission will show the players on galactic map which star system to go to accomplish the mission. Missions range from protecting a ship being attacked, salvaging / investigating a destroyed ship, and exploring a planet (There might be more currently or planned).
Star systems usually contain one of the following: Nothing, A single comet with some enemies / friendlies, a planet, and we ran into something called an "infected" star system (very hostile) and we ran into a odd place that looked like ice crystals all around making piloting difficult - very tight spaces - where we picked up scrap to sell for money. Each star system has a different color aura. 

The infected are a mystery to me. They remind me of the flood from halo.

Combat in this game is somewhat complicated but simple at the same time. As a pilot I did not get to see much of what was going on with the crew - however this is what I noticed / read / talked with the crew.

The engines, guns, and other things necessary for a ship cause the core temperature of the ship to rise. This rising temperature has to be regulated by the engineer of the ship by altering how much power goes to what. For example - i was using thrusters a lot to maneuver around the comet to dodge enemy fire while our weapons guy was firing. This nearly caused overheating so the engineer cut the power to my thrusters by half causing my manueverability to suffer so that I would not overheat the core. Just before writing this we were running away from a fight, preparing to warp jump and I was at max thrust forward while using the smaller thrusters (meant for small movements) to get as much speed as possible. All the sudden all my engines shut off. I went into first person mode and all the lights in the ship were off (it gets very dark - you have flashlights) the crew was scrambling to put out fires (things catch on fire when the ship is taking damage from the enemy), repair equipment (things break too) and reboot the ship (it shut down due to overheating - mainly because of me).

I decided to get off the piloting controls and grab my fire extinguisher and repair tool (it was already in my inventory) and go help - too late. We blew up.

This may have been prevented if the scientist of the ship had the proper programs. Programs are essentially buffs or debuffs for the player ship or enemy ship.

Luckily, the captain saved his spot. Saving works like this: The host of the server has the option to save the game state. Only the host may load and save. Pretty much, each host has their own ship. Anything a player buys for them self (there are trading stations - I bought a very good laser pistol and alcohol. Yes, you can get drunk. It makes your aim super inaccurate and gives you blurry vision) will be stored in their locker upon exiting the game.

The captain of the ship allocates funds to the crew. You cannot buy things without the captain authorizing the funds. Pretty much, the game is a co-op game that does not require real people nor does it punish having real people. The host can play with whoever, whenever, and the host's progress is saved - the ship items and the crew items.
This is a very good game. The immersion and teamwork are a type of fun I have found in only a few other games. What I really like, though, is the exploration aspect.

I wanted to try some space exploration like No Mans Sky, but without the grinding. I wanted to play a game with teamwork and communication but I wanted a casual setting. This game offers both these things combined.
If I were to lable this game it would be:
Single player / Co-op, Space Exploration, Casual, Space Flight-Sim

28920427.review:
I enjoy this game so much that I feel I want to give a review. I don't usually review anything.

As far as I know, there are no other games that I can compare this with. But if you have a group of friends or relatives to play this with, I would recommend it more. i.e. The game is much better when 5 people are playing together and who play it properly. 

Pros:
- Content - For a game that is in Beta, it does have a fair amount of content. We have been playing for about 10 hours on one game so far and we have gone around a quarter of the galaxy. We have not touched the sector commanders just yet. I think we will try one soon though.
- Updates - Whenever a new update comes out, there is always plenty to add. Most recently, the new ship - Outrider - is absolutely brilliant. I would possibly recommend it to new players too as it's easy to move around and a good starter to research. Plus, the new Ice Train level is really good and took us a little while to complete.
- Systems - I really enjoy playing as the Engineer. The ability to raise and lower power to keep the ship alive is great. The fact that each change actually changes something in real time is brilliant. So often do you reduce a bit of power from Science and everyone is moaning that they no longer can see that enemy. So you take a bit from Engineering and now the Pilot is struggling to turn around. Then the enemy knocks out Life Support and Oxygen starts to go down. So once that's fixed the core has gone into emergency cooldown. - Fantastic!
- Role Playing - To play with a group all talking to eachother and actually playing their roles properly is so good. What I mean is: The pilot flys the ship, he isn't manning the turret while the Captain is flying. Meanwhile, the Weapons Specialist is on the Bridge scanning the enemy. (Unless that's how you personally play...) But if everyone does their role and reports to the Captain, it runs smoothly and everyone does their job in the event of an emergency, it is very satisfying.
- Multiplayer - If you do find yourself playing alone, there are usually a handfull of games to join.
- AI - Yes, I put AI on the pros... I feel personally that the recent update where you have a lot of control over the AI has made it more bearable. The Captain can now add their own orders and change what the AI do when you give those orders. It's not perfect, but the developers know that. This new way of organising your Bots has made the AI a lot better.

Cons:
- Content - When you have been playing for a little while, the same missions start popping up and you know exactly where to go and who to talk to. With more content and a greater selection of starter missions to choose from would this be overcome. This is coming though so, great!
- Updates - Sometimes they don't come soon enough...
- Systems - Some systems are not complete yet. On occasion will you get something pop up and it's not in the game yet. E.g. Auxiliary system: Climate Control.
- Graphics - I personally like the graphics. But for people who have played uber realistic space sim games, the graphics are not a comparison. (Not that the graphics are bad though...)

This is by no means an exhaustive list...

---

Would I recommend this game?

Absolutely!!! For the price you are paying, you will have quite a lot of hours of gameplay in different ships and different people and different roles. E.g. Currently there are 6 ships and 5 different roles - 30 different games?? More on the way!!

28663352.review:
Das Spiel ist genial!  Und es hat unglaublich viel Potential. Alle die schon immer davon träumten auf der Startrek Brücke zu sein und als Crew zusammenzuarbeiten finden hier das beste Spiel dafür. Jede Position ob Captain, Engeneer,Pilot, etc. ist mit speziellen Aufgaben und Kontrollarbeiten bestückt, die wirklich super umgesetzt sind, und auch nicht zu kompliziert sind. Diese vielseitigen Aufgaben dann als Crew im Spielgeschehen umzusetzen machen den grössten Spass. Besonders da man koordiniert zusammenarbeiten muss. Die Reise auf der Brücke mit Warpgeschwindigkeit, oder mit automatischer oder manueller Steuerung mit den Piloten gibt einem wirklich das tolle Gefühl wirklich eine Reise durchs Universum zu machen. Das Erforschen von Raumstationen,Planeten erweitert das Spiel ungemein und wird zum grandiosen Abenteuer. Auch die Raumgefechte sind super. Insgesamt das Spiel auf das ich schon Jahre gewartet habe. Grafisch gesehen läuft das soweit ich es erlebt habe flüssig, bisher hatte ich auch keine Bugs. Die Personen,Gestalten sind zwar etwas oberflächlich von der Grafik, könnten zwar besser sein, aber dies stört nicht wirklich. Alles andere wie Sonnen, Planeten etc.  sind grafisch topp. Auch die Raumstationen sind recht umfangreich, und locken mit interessanten kunstvollen Plätzen auf. Der Handel ist ein weiterer Punkt der eine wichtige Rolle spielt, speziell zum Ausrüsten des Raumschiffes und auch für Bodeneinsätze etc.

Da es noch kein Tutorial gibt, empfehle ich auf jeden Fall die manuelle Anleitung durchzulesen, die alles Wichtige enthält, und schnell durchgearbeitet ist. 
 

Insgesamt sehr positiv. Negativ konnte ich bisher noch nichts entdecken. Daher absolute Kaufempfehlung!

28653725.review:
Now as I've played this game for around 40 hours, I think that I'm ready to review this game.

If you ever watched Star Trek, I'm sure you always loved how the bridge crew communicated and worked together in combat. It seems so EPIC and as i saw and bought this game, that was the experience i wanted. Did i get it? For the most.

If you find a proper crew which uses a microphone, you can really achieve this epic communication and cooperation between the players. It actually happens often and this game turns really immersive and engaging. What is the problem then? I would love each role to achieve greater complexity. Scientist barely do stuff when in combat, weapons specialist only does something when in combat. It all turns out as a wait for your role to have any responsibility. 

When it is your turn, though, it is REALLY fun.

5 Pros and cons

Pros:

- A decent mission-system, making the crew have a goal in mind.
- Very nice mechanics when it comes to interacting with displays etc.
- Very immersive when together with a proper crew
- EVAs
- A great varity of different ships and components which each behave very differently and you really feel that you can make your ship your own.
Cons:
- Poor FPS combat
- Planets are small and generally not very interesting
- Can sometimes be hard to find a proper game of your liking.
- Poor player physics
- Poor graphics

I'd recommend this game to anyone who enjoys the Star Trek bridge scenes. This game has a large potion of hours in it already and the game has great potential.

28466299.review:
It's kind of hard to explain exactly what this game is. It's like a mix of Artemis Spaceship Bridge Simulator, FTL, Guns of Icarus, and a few episodes of various space-based sci-fi series. It plays out primarily in first-person view (the pilot can get a third-person external view of the ship when piloting, however), and each player fills one of 5 roles - Captain, Pilot, Engineer, Scientist, Weapons officer. Every role has a few specialities which they'll be useful to have on board to help with.

In space combat, each player has a station to attend, which provides them with a selection of tools useful for enhancing the ship's performance in many ways. They also have the very high probability of panicking when something gets set on fire and completely losing track of what they're meant to be doing, which is AWESOME.

When doing away missions, everyone's job is to basically shoot everything that moves, and pick up anything that isn't bolted down. So... maybe there's a bit of Elder Scrolls or something in the mix too?

Anyway, the point is, you run around on your ship, repairing damage and manning various systems in fights, and you run around on other ships and planets shooting enemies/aliens/robots/anything else that catches your eye. And it's all co-op, played with a crew of up to 5 friends, with each of you playing a different role on board the ship. If you're missing any job, you can stick an AI in that slot to work with you, and it's possible (though not usually easy) to run a ship with only one human player. The game is obviously not intended to be played solo, however, and while the AI has a very flexible customisation system to make them behave pretty much exactly how you need them to, they're just not as entertaining as human crewmates. Even with only 2 people, the AI filling the other slots will be sufficient to provide a pretty good time, but it really shines when you have 3 or more on board the ship, working together (or at least TRYING to).

While I recommend the game, I do so with the caveat that it IS an early access title, and it isn't a finished product by any means. The content already in the game is great, and shows a lot of promise for future additions, but it isn't going to live up to everyone's hopes and dreams in its current state. If you're unsure, I recommend checking out a few YouTube videos before you buy.

UPDATE: I wrote this review almost 2 years ago. The game is still in early access, and progressing fairly slowly. It has more content now than it did, and there have been bugfixes and some fairly significant alterations to the specifics of what you do. It's still a great game to play with friends. And it keeps getting better - although fair warning that it gets better VERY slowly.

28143378.review:
Cannot reccomend this yet if you want to actually play the game now.   There is very little actual game content in yet.  That said however it seems alot of fun, especially if you are a StarTrek fan.  I would highly reccomend revisiting this game closer to completion.  I intend to update my review then.

Update:

Not many people found my review useful, so I thought I should add some detail.

Some of the graphics are quite nice, others are a little simple but overall I think its probably a good balance of playable graphics, to support 5-player multiplayer and reasonably low-end systems.

The game play is very much team-work based, you really need at least 3 players to play effectively and the larger ships would work better with a full compliment.
AI Bots can be used to fill in any position... as long as you dont mind if they suck.  The role you play as - Captain, Pilot, Wepons etc, mostly affects your stats.  So for example a Pilot can boost their ship manuvering ability, but any other player will only be as good as a level 1 pilot.  Anybody can get a scanner, but only the science officer can later gain an ability to use the scanner to find loot.

Multiplayer there are some small but very annoying bugs.  For example if the ship is warping from A-B the captain can skip the 5-6 minute wait.  I have found that this is very reliable for 1-2 players but as soon as I add a 3rd player its 50:50 if the skip option will work or not.

However after all of that, the real reason I cannot reccomend this game however is the content is only about 10% done, you will run out of main-line game play very very quickly at present.
Not only that but because I think this game will be awesome, and so much story is only partially implemented, I worry that playing now might lessen experience on release - admittedly a risk with almost any early access game.

I with the developers were a bit more communicative with development progession, however updates are reasonably regular and the team seem very competant.

If you see this game on a heavy sale, I would say buy it as a future investment but if you want a game to play now I wouldnt get it yet.

What can I say about a game I have been waiting for a very, very long time. 

First off the graphics; I like them. The look and feel of this game visually, is fun. some places you will visit are spooky and full of atmosphere and others are high tech.

Secondly, Gameplay; I love it. It is FUN ! The ships are easy to control. Ship systems are straight forward and to the point and They are not overcomplicated which keeps the fun aspect rolling. I got the gameplay down within ten to twenty minutes. Based upon the fraction ship you choose you will be given missions which you can recieve from people at space stations. Once on said mission you may have to divert to save a fellow faction member or encounter a hostile species.

Thirdly, Story; So far the main story is not there yet (BETA 11.5) but I enjoyed talking to people on space stations and via ship to ship communications. From there you are told the story of the universe which got me interested. The story is injected smoothly.

I definetly recommend this game.

26743022.review:
TL/DR, Tl/DR: Game is fun with friends, buy it. I forsee a great future in this game.

If your story is like mine, and you're tired of the same old Early Access story and you're looking for a make it or break it review, this is the one for you.


Overview:
I'd like to start off this review by mentioning that I've gotten tired of "Early-Access" games.  I'm all too sick of the same old story: early access game hits the market, promising many innovative ideas and it either fails to deliver or simply stays in early access forever (looking at you, Space Engineers and 7days). My friends encouraged me to buy this game just to have the fun of trying something fresh and new. With 16 hours under my belt (seems like so little time, spent), I can say that I've fully explored the game. I'll go over the different roles and what they do, as well as the basic gameplay aspects, concluding with a pro's and con's list. Finally, this is definitely a team-based game, which is much better with a set of friends to BS with, so keep that in mind as you read and come to your decision on the game.

(Class roles)
To start with: the game is fairly simplistic and throws you into a ship of your captains choosing. However, that's the end of it. There is no tutorial to teach you what to do, and most of what you *actually* do is fairly simplistic. If you're a pilot, you fly the ship. If you're weapons, you shoot things, if you're captain, you plot courses and choose what to buy, and if you're science or engineer, well, buckle up cause it's a *little* more in-depth than the other 3 positions.  Fortunately, even that is fairly straight forward, with a simple GUI to guide the players in doing what they need to accomplish. Overall, the positions are all fairly balanced to make everyone feel like they're accomplishing something for the average gameplay. However, that's about as far as it goes. In my opinion, there is not enough for each of the positions to do. After a while, piloting just becomes flying in a straight line, science becomes spamming all the programs, weapons becomes a matter of target practice, and engineer becomes meaningless because the reactors simply become too powerful to even need adjustments to power levels. However, that's not to say that the different positions are not fun when done with other players.
---TL/DR: Game is simple as it stands, and offers maybe 10 or so hours of actual content.

Gameplay (Space-side): 
The missions themselves are very straightforward and not too fleshed out, yet.  After a while, the game starts to feel like a shoot n' loot, which is not what I think the dev's had in mind, HOWEVER, to get to this point, you need to invest quite a few hours in exploration and fighting. Which leads me into the next part of gameplay: your ship consists of multiple parts that can be upgraded and changed with your credits earned from salvage, missions, and exploration. These items include a warp drive, shields, a hull, a reactor, programs that can be ran to accomplish a multitude of things, and processors that upgrade other ship systems. This is, by far, my favorite part about the game. You can choose to either go for the big ship with lots of weapons or the quiet ship that stealths everywhere. Unfortunately, stealth is not so much a feature yet, and just something planned. Also, there are nowhere near enough items of variable description to make it feel like an adequate upgrade path.  All in all, what they have so far makes me extremelly optimistic for what they can add in the future: a list of endless items to upgrade to, multiple new weapons and shields, etc. However, as the it stands, the upgrade path is extremely linear and quite simplistic.
---TL/DR: Ships can be upgraded (kinda), and missions are there, but need work.

Gameplay (planet-side):
Your crew can actually leave your space ship and go down to planets for a variety of reasons.  There could be a distress beacon, you could want to explore the planet for salvage or items, or simply because a mission sent you there. Most of the planets are very small and very straight forward, but this does not stop my crew from wanting to explore every single planet for what we call "lickable shit" which is a *research* item used to get special bonuses for the crew. Here comes the caveat, the "lickable shit" is quite rare and very hard to find. Some planets extend to a radius that doesn't really suit what you can do on them, so you find yourself using your very limited stamina bar to sprint into nothingness for what can seem like hours. In reality, it only takes ten or so minutes, but the time adds up when you're doing it with every planet. 
---TL/DR: Planets are very interesting to explore, but can become monotonous.

Finally, I'll sum everything up with a Pro/Con list that will hopefully convince or deter anyone still on the edge of getting this game

Pros:
Fun to play with friends
Fun to play alone
In early access, so the dev team is active and working with their community
Dev team is fast to react to community-voiced problems (hackers)
AI are capable of running the ship without other players
Exploration is new (kind of) a new concept, without being over used
Upgradeable ships
Boardable ships

Cons:
Game DOES have bugs
Not too fleshed out
Upgrades are linear
AI handles the ship TOO well on their own (looking at YOU engi-bot)
Many new features are visible, but not implemeted (scans, for one)
Questline is short and repetitive
Different positions can get boring if you don't have a group of friends to mix things up
Updates appear to be monthly, which is a downer after Space Engineers
Game doesn't have a forum yet (from what I've seen) so it's hard to communicate with the devs.

One of the funnest space games i have played.  When you get a descent group it's pretty amazing.  Engineer managing power, warp, and coolant.  Pilot aligning to warp point, or manuevering around in combat.  Scientist doing science things(uploading viruses, scanning the system or a particular ship).  Weapon specialist manning the guns, firing on enemy ships or shooting down missiles.  Captain barking orders, negotiating or intimidating the enemy, upgrading ship, setting crew member allowance for small arms, and setting the course for your adventure.  All of this while maintaining life support systems, your engine, weapon systems, while they take fire from enemy ships or catch on fire from being damaged.  You can also play with AI to kinda learn the controls and general layout of a ship, but it's not the same.

That being said, there are a lot of reviews saying everyone is helpfull, and works together.  There are some, but with online games you will find trolls.  Usually they do their mischeif before you really embark on an adventure, so it really doesn't ruin a 4 hour run or anything - and hey, for a little bit - that is fun too.

Totally worth the $24 for it - but if its on sale, snag this puppy.  I mean come on, who hasn't wanted to be scotty yellin, "i'm givin her all i got captain," while Kirk looks dramatically past the camera, while spock is telling him the unfortunate odds.

26392071.review:
Have you ever wanted to go on a space adventure with your friends? Does the idea of yelling over coms while you and your crew desperately try to survive entice you? Do you just want a good game to socialize in? If so, this is the game for you.

You and your crew take on the galaxy in an attempt to get rich, pimp out your ship, and slaughter everything in your path. You will find yourself engaging in space battles, exploring planets, and completing missions in order to amass lots and lots of cash. Your travels will take you to many places, like desolate planets, abandoned ships, and the public toilets in a trade hub. This trek across the galaxy can be done by either friends or strangers you meet on the internet. The game is good as a social game since it requires you to actually communicate if you want any chance of getting anywhere in the game.

This is, by far, one of the most UNDERRATED games on Steam. 

I think part of it is how hard it is to pilot a ship by yourself. Perhaps also the perception of a steep learning curve (it's not that hard, really!).. 

There are things missing still, like the distinct lack of Cargo Trading runs (at least, that i can find so far).

But this game has nearly everything I always want in a space flight sim! Political Intrigue, Crew Dynamics, ships to explore, a variety of planet surfaces and away missions, ship parts galore, inventory items galore, roasted Ants, it has everything!

While there seems to be little to do in a system once you jump in, that could be a matter addressed by the frequent and ongoing content additions the developers are constantly providing. 

It is a shame this game seems so overlooked. It is an amazing space game, you're really missing out. 

Especially for Linux0rz, where the presence of awesomely amazing space games like this are distinctly lacking.

26126063.review:
TL:DR at bottom

First I'd like to say, I applaud the developers. This game is pretty damn amazing, even being in early access. It is definitely a game for fans of shows/games like Star Trek that have multiple distinct roles for people to fill. The gameplay and content just in this early access is phenomenal. With that said, I'll give you a list of my pros and cons! I will be assuming a five player crew in most of the points with a few exceptions that I'll point out.

--Pros--

1] First off are the positions that you can take on the ship. Taking a class is truly defining what you do and actually see in the game. Each of the roles is specific and has talent points that enhance their ability to perform their station. During the game, as you go to planets you can pick up research materials lying around that will allow you to research additional bonuses that your crew can spend talent points one. Note, not all research is for the entire crew, some are role specific, but can offer bigger bonuses compared to the all around researchable skills.

2] Next is the universe. . . It's pretty huge tbh. Now, a lot of people are going to say that the stars and whatnot get reused occasionally and honestly, they'd be right. Honestly though, out of the near 20 hours I've been playing, it has never ceased to amaze me with how beautiful space is.

3] The space battles. These are pretty cool, especially some of the tougher fights where you're fighting 3 or more opponents. There are different types of lasers that also have a noticably different color and it makes a spectacular light show that is just amazing to watch. Not to mention you can just feel the ship rumble when the man turret fires lighting your enemy into a bright explosion of debris.

----Neutral----
I wasn't sure if I was going to add this to the list but there are a couple that I had though about that were a little hit or miss for me.

1] Lighting is a little odd. Now the hull of the ship when lasers are flying by or the star is gently glinting off the ship, all of that looks phenomenal. But at the same time, there is a little problem with the interior lighting that sometimes bugs me. There are places on the ship that even if you have the interior lights turned on, are WAY too dark to see, even using the flashlight. I find these a little troubling because when I think of space age ships, I'm thinking of REALLY brightly lit ships so you can actually see where you're going or if you have a helmet, it outlines the edges of the ship so you know exactly where objects are.

2] Planets are a little small for how big they look out the viewport. I do understand that the developers want to keep you near where stuff actually is on the planet. But the way the developers keep you from just wandering into some crazy wilderness is either by a radiation wall which, if you pass it, will slowly kill you unless you return. Or by having a giant sand critter pop out of the ground to instant nibble on your gibblets. The flipside though, is that the planets themselves look fairly well made. They may need a bit of polish to be sure, but this is early access.

3] The faction system is a nice idea, but i feel at the moment it's a bit to sensitive as well as unused for the most part. I think the only thing that has happened by screwing rep up is giving me a reason to avoid going to ship investigation sites.

--Cons--

1] First up here is the price. At the moment I would recommend waiting for either a sale or something similar before purchasing a copy as I feel, atm 25 dollars is too high. While it may be a great price for it when it goes and releases, atm it's a bit too steep with unfinished content. (Yes I know i received it for free)

2] Next are the bots. At the moment, the npcs (usually the ones with weapons not the little bug things) are exceptionally accurate, yours AND the enemies. This makes trying to either take a ship or clear a facility on a planet just a little bit frustrating. You'll eventually get it done, but it might take you 2-4 tries just to knock out all the enemies because of the pinpoint accuracy.

3] Last is honestly the textures for the characters themselves. To be honest to is just a minor gripe but I feel as if the developers decided to wait before they update the models. 

I definitely love the feel of the game, and playing it with 4 other friends is just an amazing experience. There are also a good amount of games that are on the list that are doing roleplay sessions which I can't help but imagine they're amazing.

Overall, I'd rate this game a 7.5/10 AT THIS MOMENT. The game definitely has potential, and is a definite must buy if it's during a sale. Otherwise, keep an eye on the game as it develops and offer these developers as much support as possible.

TL:DR; 7.5/10, great potential, buy during sale, or if you have 4 other friends to jump into the game with you.

25947548.review:
If I had the money, I'd give the devs a couple million dollars to turn this into a AAA multiplayer coop game. The concept is spot on.

Pros:
 - Real Star Trek like experience in multiplayer. It's amazing. It really is. If you don't believe it watch a Let's Play on youtube.
 - Incredible immersion. You are on your post. In a battle you have your job to do. You need to trust your captain to maintain a grip on the overall situation, because you sure can't, as you have to keep the reactor from exploding etc.
 - Runs smoothly at 2K on my gaming rig.

Cons:
[list]
[*]The nice way to say it is: It needs polish. Looks like a game of the very early 2000s.
[*]Even though it looks like it is from the past, it runs terribly on integrated graphics. Couldn't get any playable performance on my Broadwell laptop with Intel GPU even with every setting at the minimum and resolution at 1024x768.
[*]Little actual content in the way of missions or anything else at this point, but the devs are on it.
[*]It's less fun if you play with AI bots instead of a real crew of people.
[/list]

Verdict: If you have a couple of friends and you love Star Trek-like SciFi, go for it.

Suggestions for the devs:
[list]
[*]The shop could directly compare what's available to what's installed in your ship. Alternatively, give the engineer a nice one page overview of the ship components.
[*]A "stop all thrusters" button would be nice for the pilot, so would be piloting via gamepad.
[*]I would welcome more realistic physics for piloting: The ship doesn't decelerate on its own, keeps spinning unless you stop it with thrusters. To compensate for the complexity, you could add "stabilize" which automatically stops any rotation. The uptick of all this would be pretty cool space maneuvering a la battlestar galactica.
[/list]

25947346.review:
PULSAR is an interesting game, but somewhat lacks originality and is reminiscent of many games in the space/adventure genre. It is a great game to have a laugh with friends and explore new worlds, however the gameplay gets boring quickly due to there being extremely limited goals or missions to complete. Most of these are very bland and offer no unique reward to the player.

 The different ships available are detailed both graphically and functionally, and this game really brings a new meaning to teamwork, as the ship systems require a near-full crew to operate efficiently. The concept of the game is fun, but is unlikely to be a game that you will come back to later down the line. The planets aren't particularly detailed and lack in many areas, including map size and places of interest.

Overall, I rate PULSAR: Lost Colony a [b]6/10[/b] due to the bland characteristics, but enjoyable gameplay with friends.

Les graphismes se défendent, a la fois simple et compléxe:

Compléxe par la variété de possibilité trouvable tout au long du jeu.

-Bots: Ces machins sont extrémements archaïque (navrés aux programmeurs) et font souvent des choix binaires (là, par contre, n'y peuvent rien). -Chargement: Quand on se téléporte sur un vaisseau ennemie pour le vider (oui oui, je le fais...), un soucis apparait: Les bots nous tirent dessus lors de l'apparition sur le téléporteur... La gestions du jet pack est intuitive, les armes sont bien réglé en fonction des besoins de chacuns et chaques postes présentes ses avantages et inconvénient, créant ainsi un équilibre au sein de l'équipage!

N'espérez pas avoir toutes les perks, il y en a une grande floppé!

25811572.review:
For all of you folks who enjoy space as much as I do, this game is a nice way to explore it. Here is the views of it and what I think of it (please keep in mind that this game is in Early Access, it is being improved as we speak and/or read).
First of all, this game is a multiplayer game where you can play with friends or random people online. You are a crew aboard one of many ships to explore the vast space. Each crew member is assigned a post to fulfill. This may sound lame, but it is quite awesome. The captain gives orders, assigns missions, gives pay for the crew to use on tools and food (for healing). The pilot, well, pilots the ship (this job is my favorite, especially when fighting other ships). The engineer repairs the ship and puts out fire. He can also remove the core (not recommended unless facing death). The scientist observes the ship's status and reports any problems to the engineer. The weapon specialist can shoot the guns. Now, each crew member can do any of these roles whenever they feel like it. However, they can upgrade their talents for their specific job.
Now, as of right now, all you can do in this game is to attack enemy ships (you can teleport to their ship if it is damaged enough to have its shield down and kill the crew repeatedly until you claim the ship for your own and use it), land on planets and kill creatures that try to kill you, accept quests and do them, and explore the world. However, as I previously stated, this game is in Early Access, and it will continue to improve. There are many mysteries in this game. For example, I found a random ship that was dead floating in space. When I teleported onto it (yes, you have a teleporter you use to get to the planets and other ships), I found out that it was another ship you could decide to use, and it was full of snow. It was dead, so we (my crew and I) had to leave it, but this was the only time I saw it.
Two more things. First, if your ship explodes, your crew and you die. You have to restart. I like this feature. It makes you more cautious, which this game is supposed to make you feel. You need to play your role as if you are there. And finally, there is a manual for the game you can use to check up more on the game. Thanks for your time.

Update: This game is still awesome. The devs are still working on it. It has updates every two to three days. Honestly, it just gets better and better.

25681429.review:
Great game, however performance is quite poor on the big ships, especially on the interior. Overall, the game is great if you enjoy working as a team to defeat enemy space ships, completing missions, and visiting different planets each with new things to discover! This is sort of what No mans sky should've been, even though this games map is a lot smaller, it feels much better as you can actually make meaningful upgrades to your crew, and ship. For example, you can buy nuclear warheads for your weapons expert to launch at enemy vessles, or you can increase your ships coolant capacity or engine power etc. 

Space combat feels great on this game, and its very satisfying when you and your crew take out a gigantic enemy space ship which attempted to raid you, and loot the remains of their ship! You can sell scrap which you can obtain from enemy ships, and buy new equipment for your own ship instead to become stronger! 

Your crew is made up of a Captain who is in charge of your ship, a Pilot who pilots your ship at the captains will, a weapons expert who is responsible for maintaining weapons and engaging the enemy, an engineer who is in charge of maintaining the ships health, core temp, power etc. And also a scientist who researches new things which you can find on planets! Each crew member has a very unique, yet important role, and having a whole crew co-operating together and making the ship run feels great, it's honestly a very good co-op experience if done right.

The graphics could be a little better, especially the interiors of the ships, however the skybox, and the planets look great! One drawback of this game however, is that sometimes when on the bigger ships, you tend to get around 30-40 FPS on a pretty decent PC like mine, even though I run games like Arma 3 at around 60 FPS. However it's not unplayable, and doesn't ruin the experience for me.

The devs do bring out regular updates, and they recently added jetpacks to the game, allowing you to jump multiple times in the air. 

Positives of the game:
[*] Very fun with friends
[*] Feels great when you operate such a big ship with your friends
[*] Lots of stars/planets to explore
[*] Random NPC missions such as exploring lost ships, engaging in combat, etc.
[*] Unique roles for each crew member
[*] Upgrades to ships

Negatives: 
[*] Graphics aren't the best
[*] Sometimes performance is a little low

25519159.review:
Ahh Pulsar... A refreshing gem hidden under the heaps of small-time developers, early access garbage games that seem to plague steam these days.

I honestly believe that I've never played anything quite like it, which is why I am so drawn to it at random times throughout the day... It scratches a certain itch that I never knew I had.

Esentially you are tasked to keep a ship (yours or another captains) from being blown to smithereens by space pirates, faction security drones, Deathseekers, civilian ships, sentinals, Infected Carriers, and space police all while exploring a vast galaxy in search of fame and fortune.

Sounds bad ass right? The only catch is that there are multiple crew positions on the ship! And each are fairly vital to the success of said ship.

For instance, the pilot who flys the ship and lines it up for the next warp. The weapons specialist who mans the ship's turrets and leads boarding parties to other enemy ships. The scientist who is in charge of comms between the other vessels you come across, along with running viruses targetted at enemy vessels and quick-fix/boosting programs to aid whichever ship you find youself on, as well as planetary scans to see what lies on the surface of that sketchy looking rock your crew is about to beam down to. The engineer is in charge of power distribution among the ships systems in an attempt to keep the ship from overheating (and exploding) during battles. Last but not least, someone will have to bring together this rag-tag group of space turds and help them function like a proper unit; The Captain. The captain plots the course through the galaxy (which is always randomly generated) and decides where to loot, who to murder, and how much money you'll get to buy space booze and shiny new weapons via a crew allowance!

As it stands currently, beta 9.5 I believe, the game is really damn fun - at times...
I'd say about half of the community is willing to help out newcomers with pleasure and give them the lo-down on how the ships work and function.

The other half though... Will probably be some (irl) morbidly obese 15-16 year old captain yelling that everyone is doing everything wrong while the ship is on fire and he sits in his chair eating twinkies and contributing nothing to the rest of the crew or his ship.

With all that being said, when a crew comes together, magic begins to happen. You find yourself becoming part of the bigger picture. A truly renown Captain can issue orders from his chair for what he thinks the rest of the crew should be doing... "Full power to all systems!" , "Block their long range comms and prepare to engage!!" , and my personal favorite... "FUCK IT! ARM THE NUKES AND PREPARE TO FIRE!!" All while the crew scramble around the ship ensuring that we all don't die in space.

IMO - A ship is only as good as its captain and crew. Make friends with the people you know and trust to do good work, and you will conquer the stars.

My only bitch about the game is that the player base is fairly small. On a good day at the right time, you'll see about 1-2 dozen games for you to hop in and out of. Or you can become your own captain and try it from the management/order-giving side of the game. No shitty ports to forward, or lame ass matchmaking, just pick a ship, and your server name and see who shows up!

If you find only a few players to join, the rest of the crew can be filled with AI specific to their roles in the crew. You might want to edit how they act in the TAB menu though, because they can get a little goofy from time to time. We mainly use them to put out fires and repair the ship, but hey.. Beats trying to do it alone!

There is actually a lot more content and game mechanics I could go over, but there no exploration in that!

I have high hopes for this game! I recommend it at a 7/10 since it's still in beta.

25368943.review:
This is a great first-person starship simulator online. There are five classes. Scientist, weapons specialists, engineer, pilot and captian. When you join a game online you join a new crew each time usually, with new people, and possibly new ship. When you start your own ship, you save it and get a different crew each time when people join. Every part of the crew usually makes the decisions on where to go, what missions to take, what things you need, etc. If you are looking for a little bit of info on what you can do, here it is:

Weapons Specialist (WS): You man the weapons in the weapons bay. When on missions you are usually the one with more health and attck from talent points (TP) your crew gets from leveling up. Fighting monsters on planets and shooting and boarding enemy ships is what you do. 

Scientist: You work in the lab, do all scans, run the shields, do research, and work with programs and viruses. The lab work is done when you stuff random goo and research materials into the 'atomizer' and if gives you research material. When you do research you use those things to give your crew upgrades. When you run the sheilds you set them for physical or energy weapons that you find out about when you scan their ship. When you scan the ship of the A.I. you scan for weapons, components, etc, and it is usuallu important to know your ship's component so you figure out if there is anything you need on the A.I. ship you could get. And with virus and programs you use programs to disable or take things from the enemy ship and stop virusses the enemy ship may puts on you. You also usually get to yell at the engineer to get you fuel capsules.

Engineer: You work all the engineering stuff and systems. There are so many systems to explain that it would take me a while and a lot of time to explain it so I am just gonna leave it to: You get to learn a top to know what to press, when to press it, and how things work. There.

Pilot: Pretty straightforward. Not much I can say other than the fact that you pilot the ship.

Captian: Again, self-explainatory. CAPTIAN.

As always there is aton more things to all of these things than I explained and said, and there is so much fun to have testing and learning how to use everything.This is a great game, with real-time voice chat, so it feels like you are actually on a crew. That is a very short overview of Pulsar: Really great game.

25154783.review:
5 Players team up to pilot a starship to adventure. What can go wrong?

This can be an extremely fun game to play if you get a good dynamic crew. Captain matters most. Thus far I have only been Pilot and Captain, but I got us into some serious adventures as Captain. Ive been under the command of other Captains that were kind of dry and not so exciting - you need a Captain willing to do some crazy sh. 

You will also need to really learn your roles. Captain is a decision maker and really only needs knowledge of how to pilot and man a gun. But if youre Science Officer or Engineer, you need to know what youre doing. A good Science Officer and Enginneer are crucial to getting you OUT of situations the Captain gets you in to. 

This game seems very deep and involved after you start learning it. Its pretty much everything No Mans Sky should have been. This game is one of the most promising and exciting EA titles Ive ever played. 

There are a few cons though. The graphics look like something from 2000, which is fine - but with a graphical overhaul, this game woiuld be utterly amazing. The space graphics are fine - its the the FPS environments that are old-school. The gameplay more than makles up for this though. 

Recommended? Absolutely.

One of my first real adventures found me as a new Captain. Our Weapons Officer had a lot of experience and was somehow assigned to our ship, crewed by newbies. We encountered a very tough and very well armed friendly ship. The weapons officer spied something he wanted - that ship's cannon. 

Well, we cant fight this ship, because it has a cannon that can obliterate us in short order in direct combat. 

However, we formulated a plan to take the ship.. 

Two of us had to beam over after we hit it with our main cannon one time, just enough to drop its shields. The pilot had to keep us under it so it cant hit us with that dreaded cannon. We hit it hard, beamed over, and got intp a firefight with its crew. Our Engineer got to their Engineering deck single handedly while I held the remaining crewman at bay in the teleport room, and shut the ship down. The rest of our crew beamed over and helped us slay the remaining crewmen. 

The ship was now ours. 

I claimed our new pride and joy amid cheering of our ragtag crew. 

Then the news came from Weapons Officer Barbosa: 

We were now marked as Pirates.

25107092.review:
Basically FTL:Faster than light, as a first person multiplayer game.

Quick rundown:
-Up to 5 player space treking multiplayer game with some great mechanics.
-5 roles, all important for different reasons, and feel completely different to play.
-Random encounters and a rearranged galaxy make for a different playthrough each time.
-Planets are precrafted, but there's a fair number of them so each is hand crafted and interesting.
-When things go to shit, they REALLY go to shit, a mix of thrill and panic set in when your ship catches fire mid way through a fight in your weapons room so firstly you can't fire back and secondly you have to wait for your jump drive to charge before you're even able to escape.

Things that'll make this game great for you:
-Having or being a good captain.(Talkative[with mic], involving, and willing to act like a damn captain)
-Reading the manual for your role, cause sometimes you don't choose the weapons officer and you might have to do something more complicated than shoot a thing.
-Not be afraid to kick someone or ask to have someone kicked if they're not working well with the established crew.
-Being ok with a bug or two. It's early access.

Final note:
BUY THIS DAMN GAME ALREADY!!!
(Or put it on your wishlist and wait for a sale cause its regular price is a bit harsh...)

I am so glad that I used my No Mans Sky refund money for this early access masterpiece. I have had several of my most exciting and fun multiplayer experiences of all time in this game. 24951449.review:
When my friend initially told me about Pulsar I thought that it would not be enjoyable for me, I primarily play first person shooters and role playing games. but after 25 hours I can safely say that it has been a ton of fun for me to play. Pulsar is meant to be played as a coop game but can be played with one player and 4 bots I would suggest that you play with at least two players if not just for the beginning when you're trying to understand the game mechanics. In the current version as of this review (Beta 9.5) You don't have a set goal, you can get missions from your faction over long range comms or from finding quest givers scattered throughout the galaxy. Throughout the galaxy which is randomly generated from a seed every play through it will spawn planets, trade and repair stations, exotic shops, and other things that I will not spoil for you. Even in this games very early state it has more than enough content for me to justify dropping 25 dollars which on normal early access games, because of how most developers seem to handle early access. Luckily Leafy games seem to be on the right track with this game, they post updates to their YouTube channel often with what they are working on. After this lengthy intro, here's a list of pros and cons.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Keep in mind as this is a beta these can and most likely will change.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Pros 
-Intresting mechanics for each class to learn and utilize
-Varied classes that have important roles
-Better than average space games combat
-Immerive gameplay and exploration
-Quite a lot of planets to explore with your crew
-Unique starting ships 
-Extensive ship customization (weapons, Ship equipment, Hull, Shield, etc)
-Charecter talent tree
-Extremely fun with freinds during combat sections and planet exploration.

Cons 
-Poor graphics 
-Poor sound design
-Little variaty in planet enviroments and a small area to explore on planets

As someone who generally plays games on a laptop, I usually end up having to play games less resource intensive.

So I bought pulsar

Based off of the look from the video, you'd expect a low demand, not overly graphically intensive game. Yet I go in, and I have 15 odd fps on the entry screen. What? I wouldn't expect such low fps in a game that isn't even as graphically appealing as things like Counter-Strike: Global Offensive, or even Team Fortress 2 frankly. I've tested this on my late 2014 mac, and on  a PC. For regular PC users who can undock there cores and force multithreading this game is great, enjoyable and fun.

But for people on laptops, beware.

Very good next step to anyone who loved star trek and wanted artemis to have a multiplayer lobby. I do not regret this purchase

***Pros***
- Multiplayer client that makes matchmaking easy
- Integrated voice/PTT works really well!
- FPS version of space combat is awesome. Star Citizen and Elite Dangerous could take notes from you on raw game mechanic.

***Cons***
- Steep learning curve (admittedly if you read the manual, it does a great job of explaining)
- Not for everyone (except ST fans, any sci fi fan really)
- Graphics could be better but the game mechanics make up for it

Overall, I think this is a jewel that has a lot of potential and is still great for being in Beta. The devs seem quite passionate and engaged and I cannot wait to see what they bring out next! Plenty of growing room on this engine I think. I REALLY hope it is mod friendly though. It is worth the cost and a steal on sale.

Кратко: на любителя, у которого есть друзья с такими же интересами.

The immersion in this game is phenomenal.
First game, we were chased by these things called Infected.
We were chased through a minefield, I was tasked with shooting down their projectiles while the pilot navigated our crippled ship to warp-range for our escape.
We took enough hits to eventually bring us to imminent death, I held the line. One by one, the projectiles were precisely shot down using the last of our momentum, and we escaped to warp-range.

24840849.review:
I assemble a crew of the finest men the galaxy has to offer.
None of us are qualified to operate anything more advanced than a toaster.
We board the U.S.S Planet Smasher.
Straight to the space port to buy fuel for our adventures.
Through the warp gate we go to begin our journey.
A mission is close by on an alien planet, sounds good!
The robot raiders are scum, we eradicate them with no mercy.
We found the artifact, "beam me up boys".
Scientist tells me about a neutral ship close by.
We pay it a "friendly" visit.
Our cannons pound the ship into submission and we board them.
All crew members are killed and the ship is stripped for parts and cargo.
Once again we jump into lightspeed.
I eat biscuits from my locker.
I steal gear from my crew's lockers.
We drop out of lightspeed.
Immediately hostile ships attack and we get into a major confrontation.
Not a problem.
Pilot lines up the weapons platform to fire.
Weapon expert mows them down with ease.
We celebrate with cheers and the crew engages in small arms lazer fire on the main deck.
I give a 10 minute lecture on the health and safety issues of firing small arms inside a spacecraft and then I hand out disciplinaries.
We jump back into lightspeed.
The pilot mentions that we can make moonshine out of engine fuel...
I immediately yell to "Stop the ship"
The fuel tank is emptied and transformed into alcohol.
We party.
After drinking all the fuel we are wasted and decide to eject the core into space.
Then we slowly turn on eachother as we wait for death inside our now immobile ship.
The U.S.S Planet Smasher enjoyed 56 glorious minute's of flight and adventure before being obliterated by space pirates.
The crew commends their captain on his decisions as the game over screen engulfs us all.

10/10
You will meet some of the most pleasant people on steam and then bumble around trying and failing to operate a space craft together before your inevitable doom.

Очень интересный и оригинальный проект, аналогов попросту не существует. Соль в том, что кораблем надо управлять в коопе с друзьями, 5 человек 5 ролей: Капитан, Инженер, Ученый, Пилот, Специалист по оружию. Далее я расскажу вам по подробней чем занимается каждая роль.

[b]Капитан:[/b] Прокладывает маршрут, следит за финансами, занимается улучшениемя корабля, ну и конечно же отдает приказы 
[b]Пилот:[/b] Выполняет всячиские маневры
[b]Инженер:[/b] Следит за распределением энергии по кораблю, перегревом реактора, заряжает warp двигатель, совершает прыжки
[b]Ученый:[/b] Командный врач, сканирует системы и планеты на наличие форм жизни, использует различные программы улучшающие ваш корабль или посылает вирусы на вражеский, и многое другое.
[b]Специалист по оружию:[/b] большую часть времени стреляет из главного орудия коробля.

В игре есть элемент прокачки, у каждой роли есть собственные таланты, также есть и улучшения коробля.
А тпереь поговорим о плюсах и минусах игры.

[b]Плюсы:[/b]
- Оригинальность
- Интересный геймплей в коопе с друзьями
- Хорошо реализовано управление кораблем

- и еше много чего что я мог забыть...

[b]Минусы:[/b]
- Посредственная графика (меня это ничуть не расстраивает)
- Совершенно не возможно играть одному
- Редко выходят обновления
- Пожалуй больше минусов то я и не припомню...

Подведя итог хочу сказать, если у вас есть друзья с которомы вы можите погрузится в эту прекрассную игру то определенно стоит её купить.
