24555998.review:
An excellent space simulator! I've heard this is in the same vein as Artemis Bridge Simulator. 

I joined on with a number of friends as the engineer. After about 30-60 minutes, I'd gotten the basics down well enough. It seems that each player has enough to do that all are busy, especially during combat.

I absolutely love the tension as you warp into a new sector, with potentially hostile ships - everyone is holding their breath, waiting for the scan to come back with their fingers ready at their battlestations. Exquisite!

So far I have only played in a pre-assembled group, so I do not have experience with how jumping into a public game goes. I will say that being in a group with voice chat amplifies the experience greatly. There's something magical about hearing "Weapons are down! Give me weapons!" or "Refill my shield charges ASAP; we're getting hammered!" in the heat of battle. A really fantastically crafted experience.

The game provides a really engaging opportunity to run not only your own ship, but various kinds of ships. I would absolutely recommend this game to anyone looking to have a crack at running their own spaceship!

For those who'd like to see how the game actually plays, feel free to scope out our misadventures here on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLMZD1JcBH-MIqSwPt6sZztMEjUFf7VdwZ

or here on steam: http://steamcommunity.com/id/morjax/videos/?appid=252870

24547292.review: Have you ever wanted to explore the galaxy? Have you ever wanted to participate in galactic battles? Have you ever wanted to do missions to help others? If you want to do any of these, then this is the game for you! Tons of fun when playing with other people and/or friends.

24544651.review:
It was my first day on the job. A new ship, The U.S.S Fuccboi, hired me, I was ecstatic that they would hire a C grade engineer who barely passed his finals. I had no job skills or any clue on how to operate any components of the ship, and there was no training day, but the pay was still good enough and the exploration was more than enough to make me content.

Surprisingly we had our first mission within minutes of our maiden voyage, we needed to clear an old waystation of alien creatures. Our Captain gladly accepted asked me to prepare for warp speed, I ran down to the engine room,I had no clue where it was at the time. After minutes of searching I stumbled upon it. I quickly found the button and pressed it, the engine hummed as it charged. We were about to embark on our first mission. The ship shook as we jolted forward into the final frontier.

We arrived to our destination minutes later, to think that we traveled light years in such a short time blew my mind. An intercom buzzed.

“Alright boys, we gotta kill all these alien rat things, so everyone get your asses to the teleporter bay, or else.”

I quickly ran to the bay and pulled out my phaser pistol, It was time for action.
“Not so fast Rookie, You're not coming, we need you alive”

I nodded my head and holstered my pistol, both relieved and disappointed. Before i knew it everyone faded away. Minutes past and eventually the crew came back, beaten from the mass amount of creatures they had to deal with, or maybe their poor combat skills.

 Who knows ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

24421070.review:
How best to describe this? It's like FTL: Faster than Light, except you're playing as one of the crew and instead of running from rebels, you're running from giant killer space mushrooms. Other than that, incredibly similar while at the same time being entirely unique.

If you plan on playing this game alone; don't.

There are AI bots a captain can spawn in, but at the time I write this they're derpy and hard to control, and you'll feel the difficulty curve with every new warp jump. If you go it alone, you're gonna have a bad time.

Where this game really shines is in playing multiplayer with friends. No matter which role you take you'll find yourself both loving and hating them, making for a wonderful party or hangout game.

As a captain you might find yourself making your weapons specialist happy because you allocated mission funds for him to get a shiny new pistol, then have the engineer angry you won't get her a better repair gun right up until you tell her you were saving up for the new low-power-demand shield generator you're installing.

As a pilot you might find yourself hating that engineer because she syphoned power from your engines for a few moments until you find out she was doing it so the scientist could prepare a program for the ship's computer to double engine output for the next three minutes.

As a weapons specialist you'll appreciate every perfect broadside that pilot lines up and every asteroid he puts between you and the enemy while your weapons are recharging.

As a Scientist you'll be keeping that weapon specialist happy when you research a new Talent he can level into which gives a permenant damage buff to any gun he uses, or maybe you'll level into your own Bridge Medic talent, keeping everybody alive when ship hits the fan and you've got boarding teams arriving.

And as an engineer, you'll be spending most of your time down in the core of the ship, keeping the reactor running smooth, only popping out to save everyone's behind for the fifth time when you bound from terminal to terminal, putting out fires and repairing consoles with all the speed of a caffinated kerbal.

---

In closing, PULSAR: Lost Colony is best played with friends, and it will either cement your friendships with them forever or make you realize just how selfish the captain is when he spends 10,000 credits on a sidearm he'll never use since he never leaves the bridge.

24382114.review:
First review, so bare with me ;)

PULSAR: Lost Colony is a great game I am enjoying to explore.

The game It about you as a crewmember of a space ship.
There are 5 members that on absence of a human player can be filled with a BOT.

5 Tasks that make your ship run good or bad, depends on how disciplined people are to act as a crew.
Captain = The boss, he orders other 4 crewmembers. His commands must be straigh forward and usefull, if not BOOM !
Weapon Specialist = The gunner of the ship. Has outside view and shoots when ordered to by the captain.
Science = The Spock of the ship. Inserts virus in to enemies ships in battle, checks other ships, planets, etc.
Engineer = Controls ships energy flow, reactor temperature and keeps others from glowing in the dark.
Pilot = Stears the ship, keeps the ship aligned to jump and keeps the gunner in view of targets.

Once you joined a ship (Server) you must select witch available job you wish to take on you.
Before selecting there is possible chat or voice chat with the crew also in the server.

The missions are diverse, from finding a ship to locate something on planets, teleport to it and make the mission succesfull. On the long run I suspect the missions are repetetive dough ^^

On succes you can make your character grow with talent points, have are perosnal while others are ship/crew improvements.

The more you poke around in the universe the more chaos you inflict (difficulty).

Graphics are not the best we are used to these days. Sounds are soso to...
Music I got off by default as it distracts me.

The community is great ! If you say I am a noob, most will show or guide you through your task.
Some however kick you for even talking the wrong language. But happened to me 1 time in 4 days of play.

Its the gaming experience that I like most, specialy in mulitplayer !
With a good set of crew members you can have hours of fun with some other people !
There is in game voice chat, when done right is a realy good experience !
There is also the posibility to mute any person screaming their heads off in pure panic while afraid to die...

Most keys are not intuitive while others are to me, still you can alter them.

Documentation is available, but for me was not to informative. The community however makes lurning the game fun !

It is playable, lots of things to discover from ship management, to missions or ships improvements.
Game needs more development and then it will be awesome !

Graphics   2/5
Sound       2/5
Control     4/5
Game        3/5
Funfactor  4/5

Overall      15/25

Mobile Target

24235387.review:
Five people on a spaceship try not to explode.

You've got the [b]Captain[/b], who tells everyone what to do so nothing explodes. Little effort required.
There's [b]the Scientist[/b], who does research and manages programs and scanning so nothing explodes. Their systems are a little complex, so a little effort required.
[b]The Engineer[/b] micromanages systems, warping, and most technical stuff in a fruitless effort to make nothing explode. Their systems are relatively complicated as you have to respond to captains' orders as well as making sure  everyone else has power. Hard.
The [b]Pilot[/b] is in charge of unsuccessfully dodging attacks and responding to countless requests of "Align ship to jump!" Easy once you learn the controls. Can't do much to not explode.
Last and kinda least, the [b]Combat Specialist[/b] is in charge of manning guns and other weapons. Aim, shoot, and hope you don't die. Relatively easy. Shoot the things that are making you explode.

11/10 would completely fail to not explode again.

24218366.review:
PULSAR: Lost Colony even in early access is already a great investment and feels pretty complete despite some bugs. This is the first time I've ever said that about an early access game and hopefully it won't be the last. There is absolutely no story so I won't be covering that.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1] 
In a nutshell, imagine what you would do aboard the U.S.S. Enterprise. For those who don't know the ship specifically, imagine what is done onboard  the famous spaceship in Star Trek. You have 5 classes; each with their own upgrades that contribute to other crew members and the ship itself. Captain, scientist, pilot, engineer and gunner. I'll list these off individually to make it easier to take in.

[h1] Captain [/h1]
The captain chooses what to do, where to go and what to buy. He or she is also the one who gives you a limit on what you can spend as the money you receive goes towards everyone.

[h1] Scientist [/h1]
The scientist is responsible for buffing and debuffing ships and scanning for enemies and mines both on the ship and on foot. He can also decide whether to sacrifice shields for a more stealthy approach or keep the shields strong. He's basically the 'support' class of the crew.

[h1] Pilot [/h1] 
The pilot is self explanatory. They're responsible for maneuvering the ship to align with the current and future destinations and help to either engage or retreat from enemy ships.

[h1] Engineer [/h1]
The engineer is probably the most hectic job of all. As the engineer you're responsible for warp ignition and preparation, keeping the core cool, making sure that the right systems are on and the wrong ones off, repairing damaged systems, turning the shields off and on for ship repairs and making sure to send fuel cores up so that the scientist can continue to use his/her buffs and debuffs to keep the ship from exploding. 

[h1] Gunner [/h1]
The gunner is the most simple job. Your job is to be ready to shoot at hostiles when given the order or when you've received fire.

While some jobs are more complicated than others, every crew member is valuable and that is what I love about this game. If you're only interested in singleplayer then this is not the game for you. The A.I. isn't too bright and will end up getting you killed. 

[h1] Graphics and Sound [/h1]
Both the graphics and the sound are pretty outdated but once you play you definitely won't care. It's a very innovative and interactive game. The pictures on the store page shows you exactly how it will look.

I absolutely recommend this game without a doubt. The community is very friendly and helpful and the adventure no matter if you're starting a new game or helping someone with theirs is always different. I think that the $25 price for an early access game is a bit steep but still worth every penny. If this game is developed further and goes out of early access I have no doubt in my mind that it could end up as one of the greatest and most memorable games ever made. That is how fun this is and how confident I am about it with the direction it's in. This game doesn't require a mic to play but it is strongly recommended as constant communication is key to staying alive in the heat of battle.

24203094.review:
I love star trek.  I live for science fiction.  

I used to play a game with my friends called "what's the worst thing you would do to go to space".  "I would eat a bowl of shit" was the very first answer, and I currently have 2nd place for "eat a plate of my mother's refrigerated pubes".

I played thousands of hours of Star Trek: Bridge Commander.  I convinced all my friends to play Artemis and we played it as much as the game's awful interface would allow.  This game is about as good as I could've ever imagine Artemis could be with mods about 6 years ago.

The potatoes are finished and onto the meat:  

PROS:
+ There's a universe to explore
+ There's a learning curve to exploring it that feels "just right". 
+ Playing with your friends and training to be a well-oiled crew is easily some of the most fun I've ever had playing videogames


CONS:
- The graphics are bad.  It is ugly.  You won't like looking at anything but space.
- LOTS of content missing.  If you've ever wondered what half a game feels like, this is it.
- The current system of ship capturing and respawning is half-baked at best.  It's hard to immerse yourself when the key to success is a highly exploitable metagame

SUMMARY:

In its current state, I cannot recommend PULSAR: Lost Colony despite it being the #1 game on my watchlist for over a year.  The game is as barely functional as an early access game can barely be.  It is my hope that the development team doesn't take the current level of sales as a success and move onto other projects, leaving PULSAR in the state of development hell that the rest of us know early access titles to be.  It is my hope that this is just the beginning of a long voyage full of setbacks and the lessons we learn from them, culminating in a fruitful return, just like a great episode of Star Trek :)

In all seriousness "Pulsar Lost Colony" has probably became one of my favorite games after only a week or so of me playing it. As someone who has loved Star Trek all my life and has always wanted a game that would simulate running a ship simular to the enterprise. I can say that Pulsar is an exquisite game. There are several diffrent ships ranging from the small "Stargazer" class stealth transport. To the "Roland" class cruiser which is so huge that it could probably fit several other ships in the game inside it. Each of the ship choices are unique and have their own advantages and disadvantages. For example, one ship could have signifigantly better armor but its thrusters can't reverse. There are also some less stat based diffrences such as the engineering room being placed closer or farther to the bridge. The ship systems also go above and beyond those of other similar games. In no other game have I ever felt so proud to know the proper procedures that it requires to reboot a ships OS. The classes all feel unique however it does sometimes feel as if you may not be needed as anyone on the ship can do anyone's job with the right knowledge and talents. The game is surprisingly in depth. me and my friends decided to beam down to a seemingly empty planet only for our science officer to report that the scanner was picking up a nearby teleporter, this lead us to a secret weapons shop. Their are three playable factions in game right now, and as to not bother explaining them I will sum them up by naming them what they basicly are: Star Fleet, Semi-evil corporation, and space criminals. Each use two out of the six playable ships which are sadly restricted to their respective factions (However personally I feel it adds realism) In terms of the missions in the game, they each feel like an episode of star trek "DUDE THIS IS LIKE AN EPISODE OF STAR TREK" -My friend. The missions will have you find crews encased in cocoons, Crashed ships whose lone survivor wishes for you not to report that he survived so that he can stay with his ship, and abandoned stations full of uncontained beasts for extermination (On that particular misson a scan from our ship showed a humonoid aboard the station which we could never find, Creepy)

In conclusion this is probably my new favorite game for a long time. 10/10

23967362.review:
I really love this game!  That being said I'll start with the negatives. The game itself can become a little repetative and there is an akwardness in joining quiet or dead games especially when only one person has a mic and is talking the entire time, or you join two friends who are just going to make inside jokes all game. The difficulty level can be steep for new players figuring out the mechanics which I don't see as a negative but a maybe a roadblock for players who don't play many RNG type games. As far as the repetition goes I found that the planets began to feel very confined and cookie cutter. You'll see a cave planet, ice planet, desert planet, lava planet but each planet takes about under 10minutes to see all there is. There are some pretty cool artifacts and other ancient alien type structures to explore but as of my last game they seemed pretty empty other than for having that first time experience they became something just to move on from during gameplay. 

Which brings me to combat... the combat actually requires the crew to work together to do well. This is where games can go dead if one or more players is either too inexperienced or do not have mics to work as fluidly with the other roles. This is another issue that I think makes the game fun but can also make it hard to find players and a working crew during certain hours. I found that during off hours the AI bots did better than many players and farming by myself actually seemed to be a better option. I liked this feature from the sense of being able to farm scrap but quickly noticed how empty/shallow the game started to feel. When I started playing with players again it became a mix of either being too impatient to teach the game again and again or felt impartial when playing with experienced players who just wanted to teach you again and again.

On the flipside I would also find over about 65% of my games really pushed me into the simulation of having to pull things together on the fly and with other players I definitely made a good amount of new steam friends. The best games were the ones where everyone just started naturally roleplaying to complete the tasks at hand but it was also hard for the subconcious indoctrination of space TV dramas to not make their way onto stage. Throughout all this the need to maintain fires and subsystems while adapating to attack patterns cohesively became very addictive.  I would highly recommend this game especially to sci-fi / spacesim / co-op fans who enjoy casual/moderate core gaming. If this game had pvp I would probably having all my gamer friends playing it. In the meantime as someone who is a huge FTL fan this has been like a dream come true. I look forward revisiting this game with a friend or after a major update... l

Not as cool as I was hoping for it to be.  I don't believe it should be worth $25, even for a gracious "feed the devs" cost.  Shoddily made enemy AI and shoddily made friendly AI, clunky interactions and of course, low amount of content.  Every location you see in the trailer is in actuality every location in the game, and every planet is the same as it would be in another playthrough.  The only real charm they expect you to experience is playing the game with your friends.  [i]With your friends.[/i]  Meaning you [i]and[/i] your buddies fork over $25 for a total $125, since they don't like the idea of the 5-pack for 4-copies deal, and they haven't put it on sale at all.  Even then, it'd still be $100, if you try to buy the 5pack!  Overall I'd say not worth the money they're asking, and that's why the overall reviews count reflects the dwindling playerbase reflects the cost shows the devs haven't sold this product enough.

How would I have done it?  Well it's pretty bold but here's how it goes.  You can buy the game for $20, right, and play it as much as you want whenever you want.  BUT, you can also purchase 8 hours of game time for yourself or someone else at $5, starting when they launch it on steam, ending when the timer runs out.  It doesn't tick while the game isn't on.  As such, if you have that one friend with the loaded wallet, he/she can give up a whole $25 to assemble friends to play this game.  In the true reality, nobody should play this game more than twice, once to learn how to fail and once to learn how to win.  Any more and you'll see through the sham that is this game's minute content pool.  Additionally, if you have that group of your pals, you won't be playing this game all the time like "oh let's pop into some PULSAR right quick".  This is a one time game, and deserves a less binding price model.  And then to top it all off I'd reduce the price to $12.49 when the summer sale rolls along so I don't lose business, because I've got two orbs between my legs and a brain under the dome.

23777702.review:
As of this writing, the game is currently on version 0.9.2

A very fun co-op experience that's a little light on endgame content at the moment.

The general description of the game is a five player co-op game where each player takes a specific officer role aboard a starship. These five players working together allow the ship to be run at prime efficiency as they explore uncharted star systems and engage enemy combatants on the ground and in space. Five people are not needed to play this game. I think 3 is a perfect minimum to make things run smoothly. The Captain would also play the role of pilot while two others were Engineer and Science Officer. You could then set two bots (Weapons Bot and Pilot Bot) to man the guns.

A more in-depth description follows:

PULSAR allows up to five friends to take on the role of a starship crew. While any player in any role can do any job, each role has specific perks that make them perform their role more effectively.

The first role is Captain. The captain is in charge of the ship. He plots the course that the ship will take, manages ship finances and upgrades, gives an allowance to the other members of the crew for personal purchases, decide when to charge up the warp engine and initiate warp as well as how to respond to other vessels. He can take a diplomatic approach, militarisic approach or even extort other ships over the communications system. His skills are based on speech as well as allowing other players to move more quickly.

The second role is Engineer. The engineer is the one who keeps the ship running. He manages the reactor which supplies power to the entire ship, juggling systems by diverting power to and from ones in need and making sure it does not overheat, charging the warp drive as well as actually initiating the jump upon the captain's order. His skills are designed to make his job easier by making reactor coolant more effective, allowing ship critical systems to begin self repairs, reducing the likelihood of fires during combat and increasing the chances of successfully obtaining working salvage from destroyed ships.

The third role is Science Officer. The science officer has two primary roles aboard the ship plus a handful of secondary roles. His most important one is managing the cyberwarfare suite during combat. Managing computer viruses designed to perform actions such as kill an enemy's engines, stop their shields from recharging, siphoning credits and blocking long range distress communications as well as running anti-virus programs when his ship is the target of cyber warfare. His second role is research and developement. When research materials are brought aboard, the science officer can study them in order to learn new skills that can affect the crew in a myriad of ways such as faster weapon cooldowns, being able to run while encumbered and more efficient jetpack fuel. Other roles involve scanning ships and planets for lifesigns, EM, radiation and abnormal/dangerous weather conditions. His skills are designed around making shields more efficient, reducing the ship's signature to make detection more difficult and healing nearby crew members.

The fourth role is Weapons Officer. The weapons officer's primary role is to man the ship's weaponry, including turrets, the main gun, missiles and nuclear armament. He is also responsible for leading the away team when boarding enemy ships or teleporting down to a planet. His skills revolve around making ship weaponry more efficient by reducing cooldowns.

The last role is Pilot. The pilot's job is to fly the ship, primarily during combat, but also to align the ship with the target sector prior to engaging the warp engines. He is also responsible for getting the ship close enough to gather scrap off of destroyed ships and maneuvering into repair doks. His skills are designed to make the engines more efficient.

23735651.review:
Wow. Man, where do I even start?


So I had recently built myself a new rig, skipped a good 3 generations from Windows XP right to a Windows 10 gaming beast. This is the first game I bought and tried with it, and what a game to start with. I'm always very wary of Early Access titles because many end up not being updated after mere months, abandoned... and many many more end up being scams. This has just been awesome to play! If you're looking for Star Trek Simulator to play with friends (max 5 players), you have found it. There's planets both interesting and sometimes even dangerous, ships that could be friend or foe but often you only have split seconds to act, and the mechanics of the roles you play on the ship are complex enough to give you purpose, but simple enough to learn with a run-through of the in-game manual for that role. I have to say that the manual is definitely your friend and makes it much easier to understand what you have to do.


I'm still having fun with this game, and the geek-out moments you'll have firing up the warp drive, getting a course laid-in, and getting in to ship battles that require tight coordination by in-game voice are excellent. I definitely recommend this, and if you're looking for an inexperienced but trained engineer, contact me! (I can fill in other roles as needed, but I shine the best in Engineering I think. A good close second would be Science.)

23575071.review:
Zuerst sei mal gesagt:
Ob PULSAR: Lost Colony spaß macht, hängt allein von den Leuten ab, mit denen man Spielt. Wenn zwei oder drei Spieler dabei sind, die öfters mal reden und der Rest sich zumindest ab und zu mal im Chat meldet, kommt dabei eigentlich schon eine gute Spielerfahrung raus. Ich persönlich bin zumindest auf den deutschen Servern eigentlich nur auf nette Mitspieler getroffen. Ich weiß aber nicht, wie viele deutsche Lost Colony noch spielen, deshalb kann ich für nichts garantieren. (Nicht-Deutsche waren auch meist freundlich)

Der Spielspaß steigt auch mit der Anzahl der Mitspieler, wobei es mit weniger als vier nicht wirklich viel Spaß macht, und allein oder zu zweit hat man es echt schwer. Auch ist es nicht gerade lustig, wenn die anderen noch Anfänger sind. Aber ich konnte das ganze zumindest schnell lernen.

So, soll ich eigentlich noch wirklich was zum Spiel an sich sagen? Es gibt über 800 Reviews, aus denen man auch einiges erfährt. Deshalb schreibe ich hier einfach mal meine persönliche Meinung zu den einzelnen Rollen

Captain:
Der hat's eigentlich am einfachsten und am schwersten gleichzeitig. Am einfachsten, weil er normalerweise wenig zu tun hat, und am schwersten, weil er sich mit der Ausrüstung des Schiffes auseinandersetzen muss. Das ist nicht immer ganz übersichtlich, weshalb der Job am Anfang der schwerste der Crew ist. Mit Ausnahme des engineers vielleicht

Pilot:
Der Pilot richtet das Schiff für warps aus, bringt es in Kämpfen in einen Winkel, in dem der weapon specialist die Gegner treffen kann, und manövriert es in die Teile, in denen es repariert wird. Die Steuerung ist recht schnell gelernt, und an der ändert sich auch nichts, abgesehen davon, dass manche schiffe träger oder langsamer sind als andere. Und es macht auch Spaß, durch ein Minenfeld zu fliegen -und dabei alles unter Kontrolle zu haben-, während der Rest der Crew in Panik verfällt^^

Weapon Specialist:
Dessen Aufgabe ist auch ziemlich klar: An eine Kanone gehen und die feinde unter Beschuss nehmen. Davon gibt es mehrere, und eine kann auch durch einen skill von den anderen benutzt werden kann. Welche, hängt auch immer von der Ausrüstung des Schiffes ab. Im großen und ganzen ist es wohl die einfachste der fünf rollen, ransetzen und schießen. Auf große Entfernung ist das aber auch nicht einfach, und auch hier kann man sich verbessern.

Engineer:
Die nach eigener Erfahrung undankbarste Rolle von Lost Colony. (Vielleicht hab ich auch einfach nur mit den falschen Leuten gespielt?) Der engineer kümmert sich um die Energieverteilung unter den Systemen und achtet darauf, dass der Reaktor nicht überhitzt. Außerdem bereitet er jeden warp vor, was auch irgendwie das einzige ist, was die Mitspieler mitbekommen. Mehr gibt es eigentlich nicht zu sagen

Scientist:
Die wohl nutzloseste Rolle von allen, kann eigentlich auch weggelassen und vom captain übernommen werden. Manchmal aber ist er wirklich nützlich. Man verfügt über ausgerüstete Module, (ich nenn die jetzt einfach mal so) die im Kampf einen temporären Vorteil bringen, wie z. B. das Herunterfahren feindlicher Schilde, oder das sofortige aufladen des warpantriebs. In letzter Zeit wurde allerdings versucht, die Rolle durch Artefakte mehr Relevanz zu geben. Hier bin ich aber nicht wirklich informiert

Fazit:
Ja, mein Fazit steht eigentlich oben. Mehr gibt es nicht zu sagen. Den Rest muss jeder selbst entscheiden.

Ach, und wer noch einen Piloten braucht, kann mich gerne adden^^

While this game does not look as impressive as other games of these days, including the fact that this game is in early access, it's still lots of fun. Players who have played FTL: Faster Than Light will see lots of similarities between the games. Even the damage system is similar.

The game has a wide galaxy to explore and tons of room for roleplay. Sadly, the planets don't have much variety yet, but the sectors/systems are lots of fun to explore. Some have black holes, some have empty ships, some have large cruisers as big as your ship and some have drones. 

Every ship is well done and suits different playstyles, such as stealth and kill on sight piracy. The UI is not beautiful but easy to navigate.

So far, I am quite happy with the community.  On some occasions though, trolls might join the game, disable your ship and leave instantly, which is quite an inconvenience.

This game does not have a tutorial yet, only a large manual and a noticeable learning curve.

23374097.review:
I've been playing the Early Access version of PULSAR and I have to say I'm impressed. I normally avoid early access after being burned by Dean Hall and DayZ but this game had me hooked within an hour.

The sense of exploration and adventure is really the focal point of this game, and they're things that a lot of games set out to achieve. The problem with most games out there is that their goals are attainable by just about anyone who picks them up. Challenges are set by the player themselves, and gaming (even in many multiplayer games) can feel like a very solitary experience.

PULSAR requires coordination with players (I really don't recommend this game unless you have at LEAST 3 other people to play it with) and that coordination is what drives this game. Suddenly it isn't the individual that chooses the difficulty and the challenge, it's everyone. You all work together and stand aside one another in the face of adversity--be it brutal enemy starship fights or exploration of labyrinthine caverns on distant worlds.

The devs have taken a very simple idea and made it into something very fresh and inspiring. It's hard to adequately describe the rush of emotions you get when winning your first starship fights as a team...or exploring sectors and sending away teams on investigations. 

This is one of the few TRULY "cooperative" games out there in recent years. I strongly recommend that fans of co-op games and sci fi/space games keep a close eye on this. If you aren't an early access type of person, add this to your wishlist and track it in its development.

23368877.review:
[b]PULSAR: Lost Colony[/b] is a cooperative game in a futuristic space faring setting.  Up to five players collaborate to tackle exploration and combat objectives.  

Each player assumes a role in a small starship crew: Captain, Scientist, Pilot, Engineer, or Weapons Specialist.  Working together, the crew travels across a randomized galaxy to overcome various obstacles.  Exploration missions task the crew with travelling to remote locations to retrieve items or investigate an area.  Combat includes ship-to-ship battles as well as gunfights between individual players and opposing NPCs.  Enemy ships may be boarded and seized, or destroyed for scrap.

Each player has specific responsibilities.  The Scientist operates the ship's sensors, shield configuration, and opens communications with other vessels.  The Engineer manages the ship's power systems to ensure various parts of the craft are able to operate, without overheating the reactor.  The Pilot flies the craft and acts as the crew's "eyes" - identifying hazards or items of interest that do not appear on sensors.  The Weapons Specialist mans the ship's turrets and acts as the craft's security officer.  Finally, the Captain (the player hosting the game) is the crew's decision maker - managing missions, diplomacy over comms, and overseeing the crew's finances.

Simply put, [b]PULSAR: Lost Colony[/b] is a great game.  For a better understanding of the game (without playing it), check out [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zwhbnW-o80c]this gameplay video[/url].

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zwhbnW-o80c

23309520.review:
PULSAR : Lost Colony.

Que dire sur ce jeu qui possède seulement deux personnes dans le staff pour le développer. Premièrement, nous sommes face à un FTL en version 3D. Le jeu propose l'espace comme jeu et nous avons à disposition un vaisseau. Il faut prendre en compte UNE chose : il faut être 5 pour que le vaisseau tourne correctement sans trop de panique. (à 3 c'est possible mais plus tendu surtout si le vaisseau est un croiseur.)

Les Stations spatiales, les planètes sont très bien foutus mais un problème est récurent et ne sera peut être jamais changé : c'est vide...les stations spatiales sont plutôt vides (entre 10 pnj en moyenne et 1 sur 15 qui donne une quête) et les planètes c'est le désert de gobie. (à part des monstres, robots vous avez peu de chance de croiser un PNJ pour une quête)

La diversité des planètes est par contre juste super intéressante. Mais toujours le problème est qu'arrivé à un moment nous ne prenons plus le temps de tout fouiller correctement grâce aux améliorations faites par le scientifiques.

Chaque classe est importante, de plus il y a des niveaux et donc des points à attribuer qui aident soit l'équipage, soit le joueur lui même.

Il manque aussi une grande chose : lorsque vous avez tué un certain vaisseau dans la galaxie et que vous récupérez son canon : pratiquement plus rien ne vous fera barrage.

Si je conseille ou pas ? Bien sûr que je le conseille pour ceux qui ont envies de vivre un FTL mais en 3D avec des amis.

22929939.review:
PULSAR: Lost Colony is actually a very well done game by a small indie developer, and it's about you serving and/or captaining a starship and going on a journey through space.

Been with the game since Beta 3, and I can assure to anyone thinking of buying this game that tons of progress has been made since then. The most recent major update in Beta 8 allowed you to hail other ships, instead of just flat out fight them the second you see them. It really adds to the immersion of the whole game.

With any game there's bugs, but none are overwhelmingly large enough to be game breaking and most are minor, for now. The devs have done a good job in QA testing their game and each update. Whenever they see a bug they usually do their best to fix it ASAP. Sometimes a bugfix will come in a patch version big enough to actually introduce a few tidbits of new content too. Always a good thing.

Some things are actually still missing, for instance; there's some key elements to the lore that are implied but not written in stone or shown in the game just yet. Updates have done their best to bring in more lore based content alongside meaningful core mechanics to the game. It should be made clear the devs are focusing on getting all core mechanics down first, before focusing on any big time content. Regardless, the game is still a bit vast in these initial stages.

Some people on the forums on the dev's website have suggested removing warp times and simply allowing a Captain to choose when to skip a warp. This would likely be a very good idea; if your ship has been damaged heavily in a firefight, being in that warp gives you the time to do what you can to get it battle ready, despite whatever shape it's in. Furthermore, let's say your crew is RPing? It would be perfect for RPing crews to use that time inbetween warps to socialize amongst crew and advance their own story. Despite these reasons, the devs have yet to make any adjustments let alone make any comments about this (to my knowledge). This so far, in my view, the only major con.

Pulsar: LC is a well done game. There are things that need to be done, but for what it is right now, it is a well done game.

22836579.review:
TAVelcro, Captain Velcro to be exact. I am the C.O in charge of the C.U Carrier Class "Paper Airplane" so cleverly nicknamed by Admiral Hill. My crew is of five members to whom I own my life and vice versa. On weapons is Justin who has the best record of shot to hit in the entire galaxy. On engineer is Sabakyo, a veteren in the fleet and second to none when it comes to reactor management. Rey is our pilot, he is new to the crew but quickly became close friends with everyone. Bovice on science, outstanding record from the academy graduating top of his class 4 years running. 

Our usual missions are that of scrap gathering.  We do, however, receive a few agressive missions like defending a mining base, or collecting rouge scout drones by any means nessasary. But last week, everything changed. There is word of an Intrepid class ship who has stolen weapons from the fleet and using them to extort civilian ships and trading outposts all across the galaxy. They are very clever and have thus been unable to be located before they strike and dissappear. We have recieved orders from CU Command that they have recently tried to sell children for credits at a trading station on the outskirts of Mineus Thrive not 5 Warps from our usual gathering spot. We have been ordered to investigate the incident report and find out why the trading depot has been radio silent.

After a short briefing, we quickly begin preperations and head out to the trading depot. The journey was quite uneventful though I can tell the crew is a bit nervous. Hell, I am myself. "Captain, we are dropping out of warp in 10 minutes." My science officer announces to me through comms. Leaving my quarters, I head towards the bridge. Shortly after we drop out of warp to see the wreckage of the trading depot we were tasked to locate. It was horrible, debris everywhere. If not for the quick reaction time of our pilot, we may have had a collision. "Science, see if there is anywhere safe to teleport to and perhaps their computer has information as to what happened here, also do a scan for any lifeforms. Pilot give us some breathing room, i'd prefer not to have a hole in our hull before we face our true objective." I calmly order towards my crew.

"No lifeforms sir, but there is a few blast doors that seal off near their comms array we may be able to get into, I'm sure if it's anything like the depots back home, they'll have at the very least audio logs of the events leading up to their destruction. Permission to beam abord?" Science hastly says after a few beeps from his station. "Granted, take weapons with you, I'm sure Colonel Justin would like to stretch his legs" I say.

The boarding party went quite fast and sure enough, Bovice was able to return with information as he anticipated. It would seem the depot refused a deal from a recent ship who ported at the depot, calling themselves the Grim Cutlass. Out of anger they opened fire on the depot, according to these logs though, they only fired once. The devistation from just one shot from this weapon was unfathomable. This in no way helped with the nerves of my crew and I was unsure of how to reasure them that this wouldn't be us if we arent careful with how we approach the AWOL ship. With little delay, we warp in the direction of the last warp trail left behind assuming it must be our culprit.

My Scientist Bovice warns me our odds of survival are increibly low. I order Engineering and Science to turn off everything and then ordered the crew into our Exo-suits. We have yet to be detected by the Grim Cutlass so we have the element of suprise. After a few moments of debate about how well our shields and hull would stand against this weapon the enemy ship has onboard, It is clear the best corse of action is to unload as much fire power we can into them before they can react. The hopes is to disable their weapons and then perhaps get them to surrender. Without their main turret active, they should crumble with fear. We drop out of warp and our scanners confirm it is the signature for our foe, the AWOL CU ship self named "Grim Cutlass". My report from CU Command says the weapon they stole when they went AWOL is a prototype weapon called the CU Long Range. We've seen it's power solely from the rubble it left behind.

"Justin, charge main cannon, load shield piercers and fire at their weapons. Science, load our barrage program, Pilot, face the enemy and be prepared to dodge whatever return fire you can. Engineer, dont let us blow up" I command. "No pressure Sabakyo" Science snickers. Like clockwork, weapons locks on with shield piercer missles and charges our main turret, engineer like conducting flight of the bumblebee works at redirecting power as needed while maintaining a low core temp. Pilot ties what appeared to be a rambo bandana across his forehead and cracks his knuckles. Science was sciencing the shit out of his station.

Our missle flies at almost same time the main cannon hits their shields, our auto turrets fire a few rounds of railgun ammo as our missle hits dead on. "Captain! Their weapons are disabled." Science shouts "Hail them!" I say
On screen was the captain of the Grim Cutlass, eye patch, exotic fur coat. Suprisingly it was a female, but more now a pirate than an ex-CU Captain. "Cowards play! she screems "How dare you fire upon an unprepared opponent! But if you leave now then i'll give you a head start before burning this sector alive to hunt you down. and KILL YOU SLOWLY" The crude space pirate sneers. "This is Captain Velcro of the Colonial Union. You are to hereby surrender yourself and your ill gotten ship to us immideatly or face destrustion." I say extremely proud that our sneak attack worked. 

"I refuse, but I find it absolutely hilarious that you are so arrogant that you think you've won." She barks then closes comms. "Sir! They are firing their main cannon!" Science screams. "But how?" I ask. In a blink of an eye, a large pulse of energy streaks across space towards our ship. This is it, our end i think to myself as our pilot barely manages to roll the ship out of its way. "Captain! Our engines and shields are down!" Science proclaims after taking a moment to see we are still alive. "It would seem their main turrent is on a seperate power source."

"Load the nuke..." I barely can believe i said aloud knowing that we should only use it in dire situations and admitting we needed to use it was admitting this was most likely our last rodeo. "Sir! If we do at this range, well be hit by our own explosion!" my Weapon's Specialist exclaims. "He is correct, sir." My Scientist says. "Captain, I could fire full reverse thrusters and put some space between us" The Pilot states. "Doing so will require me to give more power engines and our reactor cant handle it, not after the effects of that blast we took.." Our faithful Engineer adds.

"You heard me crew!" I shout. "Our window of opprotunity will be very short. If they get another shot at us we are finished. I want Science to load all our shield recharge programs, Engines alot all power to science and weapons. Once the nuke is launched, full power to engines and full reverse. I will detonate the warhead manually." I command with absolute confidence in my crew. "Science get on a railgun and shoot any missles they send our way once programs are executed."

Sitting there with my hand over the detonate button, my crew scrambles between their roles as the Grim Cutlass and ourselves send volley after volley of lasers and missles at eachother. I can see the damage to our systems on my screen before me piling up. Everything is going quiet around me despite the carnage. I can faintly hear Bovice saying they are firing the weapon again. Our nuke was now in range, but so were we. I close my eyes and exhale.

The Grim Cutlass is no more, but nor are we.

10/10 would totally Martyr my crew again.

22823566.review:
You and four friends (or bots) can now pile into a star ship of your choice and adventure across space. It's not the prettiest game out there by far, but that means it's more accessible to lower end systems! And who knows? Might look better as time goes on, but I wouldn't expect it to. 

The game itself seems to be pretty in depth with the systems. Plenty of bars and numbers. Your crew is separated into five classes.

Captain
Weapons
Scientist
Engineer
Pilot

When you make a server, you can fill empty slots with bots by pressing TAB and the menu should be right there. Игра не стоит своих денег и сейчас я постараюсь обьяснить почему:
1) Графика - графика в игре откровенно говоря слабовата. В 2015 игру с такой графикой просто стыдно выпускать. Движок Unity в принципе может выдавать хорошую картинку (взять хотя бы  Rust, Guns of Icarus). Видно что разработчики не имеют большого опыта в создании игр учитывая то что сам по себе движок с низким порогом вхождения
2) Геймплей - Геймплей базируется на двух составляющих: это полёты на космическом корабле и высадки на планеты с последующим их изучением... и опять-таки выбор кораблей скуден даже по меркам альфа версии, механика управления кораблём конечно занимательная но опять же есть проседания по классам (например за капитана довольно скучно играть), плюс сложность в освоении проходит после часа ознакомления со всеми компьютерами.
Высадки на планеты это отдельный разговор. Во первых их очень мало, во вторых на них просто нечего делать и высаживатся только для того чтобы посмотреть на пустую локацию на которой находится 1 айтем для подбора и пара противников после первого раза просто не хочется... 
3) Музыка - музыка как и всё в этой игре хромает на обе ноги... 3 композиции это согласитесь мало.
4) Сюжет - сюжета пока что не завесли, поэтому ничего сказать про него не могу (ни хорошего, ни плохого) 

Вердикт:
Не поймите меня неправильно, мне очень нравятся игры на подобную тематику. Космос, атмосфера одиночества и подобные вещи меня очень сильно привлекают и я надеялся на положительные эмоции купив эту игру, но получил только разочарование... А жаль! Идея неплохая, но реализация подкачала. За почти 6 часов я увидел в игре без преувеличения всё что можно было увидеть... Есть более лутшие проекты (даже находящиеся в раннем доступе) на похожую тематику, на которые можно потратить свои кровные...

22256706.review:
I'll fully admit that it took me a while to decide if I was going to purchase this title or not. The graphics in the screen shots and the videos made me wary that this was yet another Early Access title that does the same thing that other, bigger, prettier games do so much better. (And lets be honest, if you've played Early Access you probably know exactly what I mean.)

Then, I decided that I would go on YouTube (something I never do) in order to see what the game play was actually like. What I saw intrigued me enough that I actually bought an Early Access title for what I thought was a lot of money for such a simple looking game. 

So far, I'm pretty amazed by what Leafy Games has managed to put together. After you play this, you'll wonder why it took so long for a game company to see space combat through a cooperative lens. 

The game isn't done yet, don't get me wrong, but what it does is something that no other game has really attempted with any degree of success. It takes the somewhat tried-and-true formula of a space sim/roguelike/shooter/RPG and instead of giving each player their own unique starship they make you cooperate to run that one starship well.

The five classes they have in the game are mostly well balanced around one another, as each class 'controls' a particular section of the ship. Some roles, like Engineer, involve pushing buttons and pulling levers to keep the ship from overheating and providing power for the other roles to use. Science is the eyes and ears of the ship while providing offensive and defensive buffs through power allocated by the Engineer. The pilot flies the ship and collects space-loot while ensuring that they follow the captains flight plan. There's a lot there, and while it might be confusing your first game nothing is so complex that it will take more than a half-hour to learn it. (Also, the user manual is surprisingly useful for a first-time player that prefers not to engage in trial-by-fire.)

The community thus far have been very helpful and nice, which is also a refreshing change of pace, although there are the obligatory trolls/children that will join into your game to shut off oxygen to your ship or purposefully start fires/destroy subsystems for the sheer hate of it. So far, they're relatively few and it's generally pretty easy to recover from any of their hijinks. It's also a small community, so after a while you'll probably know enough people to steer clear of any jokers you might encounter. 

Obviously, the game is growing, and really my only critique is that there needs to be a few more things that the Captain can override as far as crew decisions that could be deemed 'griefing', such as firing off nuclear warheads or turning off shields mid-combat. 

The game play is as fast or as slow as your group can handle. Planets are relatively relaxing without any real threat of losing anything, death is painless as you have infinite clones (Although in hardcore mode you don't get a save at all, so you better not all die at once or it's game over.), and voice chat is almost a must if you really get into this game. Bad decisions are punished hard and fast, often times without you necessarily knowing what went wrong. (Such as shooting at a -much- more powerful ship than your own, only to be one-shot in return because Science didn't bother to scan the enemy ship to determine it's relative strength.) You won't blow up out of nowhere due to any one crew members mistakes though, so don't concern yourself with the engineer accidentally ejecting the warp core or hitting the wrong button and killing everyone instantly.

Most games that label themselves as 'cooperative' are anything but cooperative. This game is a breath of fresh air into the space sim genre and I hope Leafy follows through on this concept and continues their track record of timely updates and great ideas.

As my last parting thought, if you're at all a fan of Star Trek and always wished there was a game that finally scratched that itch that nothing seems to satisfy, this game is literally tailor made for you. Even if you -don't- like Star Trek, this game is worth a look and a purchase just for the innovation they've already put out into the gaming universe.

I've had this for a while, but it took quite some time before it got into a state that I would call worth to play. Now however, this is definitely something you should pick up if running your own starship sounds intriguing to you. Get some friends together and explore, trade and fight.

The new mission system is great, it gives you cool objectives like finding out why a ship stopped responding, only to find them dead in space and infested with... something... :)

Movement is stiff, the gunplay is very basic - but there's enough dials, switches and screens to play with to make this fun top play nonetheless. You can play this alone with bots, or use AI to supplement your human crewmates. Hopping into a multiplayer game is super easy, even hosting a game behind NAT works without any manual configuration. Voicechat is built in, which is a giant plus. There's definitely a lot of polish still needed, but the last patches have added a lot of that, as well as major new features. 

It's not finished, but definitely worth the price of admission. Get it on Humblebundle so you get a DRM free copy as well as a Steam key.

Update May 2017: The game now supports VR and is really great to play in glorious 3D! Devs have been updating the game regularly and adding more missions, ships and systems. Space combat has gotten a lot better, though on-foot gunplay is still basic. Still, if you ever wanted FTL in 3D and with multiplayer, this is it. Continued updates and the dedication of this dev make this a no-brainer. Still a resounding thumbs up from me.

22192543.review:
A very impressive game. 5 players get a spaceship, and adventure around the galaxy doing anything they like. The classes are all well designed, though the Scientist and Engineer could do with a few more responsibilities. The ships and their class-related functions are easy to learn how to use - after my first "game" (30 minutes of gameplay, "Game Over," everyone left) I had mastered a role and learned quite a lot about another two. The enemies (generally) aren't over- or under-powered, unless there are more than about 3 of them, in which case one should leave. Quickly.  

One of my largest problems was the character model quality. While it doesn't affect gameplay, I'm very fussy when it comes to graphics quality. Also, there could be a bit more variety in terms of the ships (not the components, the ships themselves).

I do think that the price was a bit too high, however. Personally, I would have been more willing to pay around £15, rather than £18.99. Alas, not many things are perfect - but this game isn't too bad.

VC em capitão que decide para onde ir, engenheiro que controla força direciona energia pra onde quer, cientista que usa softwares para ajudar a nave levantar escudos, ter velocidade em poucos segundos, e invadir o sistema da nave oponentes, faz pesquisas que ajuda e todos ou a si mesmo (pesquisas sem informações e sem explicações) são pesquisas sem muito o que fazer é só clicar no menu e escolher sem nada saber lol. O especialista de armas que pode usar uma ou duas coisas a mais. O cienteista também pode curar, o piloto só controla a nave ele pode guiar ate a doca para reparos e manter a nave na direção certa para vencer a batalha ele depende muito do engenheiro para saltar do setor em caso de emergência. Todas as classes pode usar qualquer area de trabalho, o que significa que ou os outros ajudam, ou atrapalham. Tem muita gente que usa password e menos server que não usa. Poucos brasileiros, É beta estão no meio ou algo assim. O esporte de usar a pistola para entrar na outra nave e vencer é dificilimo. O pesonagem seu perde muito fácil. Tem varias naves quase 8 eu acho. É legal e tem a aparência de jogos directx para quem sabe o que estou falando vai entender como são realmente as texturas. A comunicação multiplaye é excelente.

I joined my first game as a new player, as the captain of course!

21930799.review:
Quite a price to pay for the full experience with friends. However, if you are able to get a full group (5 people) of friends it creates a great experience. I've played a few bridge simulators and there are none better than this. There are 5 different roles and you cannot only travel around a 3D huge scaled ship, you can board other AI ships to take them over, land on planets and loot, and shop in local shops. Team work is required!

I would not recommend this title if you are playing solo since it is hard to find other teams to play with (especially if you do not have a mic!). The AI for your crew is not that great (but better than no one) and would again, would not recommend playing solo especially for a single player experience. Playing with random crew members can be hit and miss, especially since there are quite a number of players that feel the need to just wreak havoc to your ship just for fun.

Otherwise, if you can get a group, I highly recommend this title. Perhaps $25 is not the best price though. If this game was $10-$15 it would be perfect.

21804622.review: Like most early access games, this game shows a lot of potential.  They nailed on the head the fun part of cooperative and exploration games.  This game really forces you and your crew to work together to fight off hostile ships, or explore planets.  Unfortunately, that's pretty much all the game has to do.  There's a complex galaxy full of countless planets and systems, and each of them is one of 3 things, a planet to loot and maybe shoot something, a mostly empty sector to shoot down an enemy ship, or a trade station.  I would say if this game is on sale for a few bucks, pick it up for you and some friends and enjoy yourself for a few hours, but after those few hours, you'll probably have seen most of what the game has to offer currently.  Once they begin to add some more diverse content to the game regularly, then I would recommend this game for full price.

Although my computer reacts very shitty on this one (15-30 FPS, which has something bound to resolution), i must DEFINITLY recommend this game.

[h1] Core of the game [/h1]

You start off in a ship of choice (A cruiser, a stealth cruiser, frigate, etc.), and you must work together with each other to "find the Lost Colony". Although im not sure this is implemented yet, the goal of the game through my experience, says we need to repel the "infected", a organic apocalypse growing through space (and very lethal!). This may only be accomplished by [spoiler] buying nukes in exotic shops [/spoiler], or if youre a tactical genius, you may just find another way. In any case, teamwork is definitly a thing here, and tactics on what to upgrade, since the game has a "FTL-ish" styled increasing curve in difficulity, known as the "chaos level". This increases each time you jump, and you cannot counter the increase of the chaos level. Also, besides from being inside your ship, you can explore planets (which currently are static locations), board enemy ships (Better get a better gun first...), which really extends the potential of the game. I can't wait to see what the future of this game will bring.

[spoiler] But please fix the resolution problem, if this has something to do with the technical difficulities of PULSAR: LC.[/spoiler]

21718466.review:
This game is very impressive. I thought it would be another bad early access game as soon as I looked at the trailers. Much to my delight, I was wrong about this game. 

As soon as I jumped in I had absolutely no clue what I was doing and went around and started flipping switches. This all would've made sense if I had just read the manual which is actually very useful.

As of right now, this game has a decent amount of content for being Alpha. There are also not that many bugs and apparently this is because the dev team actually want to focus on the bugs and roll out content in Alpha. The framework is strong so I think that the content will come fairly quickly and consistently once they reach that stage. 

Multiplayer works amazingly. The Teamspeak integration allows players to enjoy the best in-game voice chat that I have ever used. Voice comes through crystal clear and doesn't have any real problems. 
 
There are not really any major bugs that I have encountered so far which is one of the reasons I decided to pay for this game and not pirate it.

The dev team also does not plan on raising the price in the future so if you don't want to jump on board the early access train, you can certainly wait. 

With that being said, I hope everyone purchases this as soon as possible so that the developers have more money to work with because they have an early access project that is actually worth funding and seeing through.

As of right now, I would give this game an  8/10. Performance could probably be improved a litte bit and the AI is a bit wonky. Combat is also a little frustrating right now but I know that it will be improved as time goes on. I really can't wait to see what all Leafy Games has in store and I know that once they reach release, this will definitely be a 10/10 game. No doubt about it.

21644321.review:
I usually don't write reviews, but I think this game is very worth mentioning.

[h1]What is PULSAR: Lost Colony?[/h1]

I would describe it as a [b]3D multiplayer FTL[/b]. The player, with up to 4 other crewmates, travels by the galaxy in a spaceship. Every person will be asigned to a role, being these the Captain, the Pilot, the Engineer, the Scientist, and the Weapons Specialist. Cooperation of all crew members will be needed to survive each threat they will encounter(mostly, enemy vessels or drones in space, aliens in planets).

I recommend to the person insterested in the game to watch some videos, because it really gives the sensation of being part of a vessel crew, giving a lot of tense situations, with the pilot running away from enemy shots, the captain giving orders, the WS trying to hit the enemy vessel and, when everything seems lost, the engineer screaming "WARP DRIVE CHARGED AND READY, WE'RE FUCKING GOING OUTTA HERE" and jumping to hyperspace after an eternal time lapse where the drive took forever to charge.

Perfect for playing with friends. It needs more content, but game gets updated every month with new features. I'm really looking forward for this game to be completed.

21607543.review:
The game that would result in someone getting FTL and Guns of Icarus into a bed together would be glorious.  Luckily, Leafy Games did it, and the result is glorious.  You can take control as one of five classes: Captain, Pilot, Scientist, Engineer, and Weapons Specialist.  Each one has their own upgradable abilites that help them along their journey.  Each class is also extremely fun.  Even the Scientist, who does nothing but scan ships and deploy viruses, is an intense and satisfying class.
Along with fun classes are the fun scenarios.  From battling ancient sentries to bringing someone a lost sandwhich, each scenario and quest is fun.  Each scenario is also very balanced.  The bosses feel hard, but will never induce rage.  Sentry drones are easy to take out, but they are more than a mere nuisance.  You will never get bored playing this game.
Possibly the best part of the game is the community.  While their are some less than mature people playing (there have been ships named the H.M.S. Dicks) you will always be greeted by friendly space trekkers willing to help you when they can.  This is the type of game where friendships are made.
All in all, this is one of the best games I've played, even though it's in Early Access.
The worst part about the game are the few bugs that will most certainly be fixed in the next update.

Pulsar is unlike any other co-op game I've ever played, since everyone's experience is their own.

I learned how to play Engineer first just in case I wanted to kill my crew for the heck of it.

I joined a crew that was seemingly a tiny bit dysfunctional. Decided "hey, Im gonna screw these guys over"

Acting normal and such when I hear burning. Go to investigate. Entire life support room is on fire. I think nothing of it and put it out and repair the system.

Keep plotting to kill crew until I be good guy again when the core is on fire. Think nothing of it since we just got out of combat.

Another system catches on fire. Go to put it out. See our ten-year-old weapons officer walk away from the fire. Get suspicious. Tell no one.

Going on our merry way when suddenly ship power goes out. Go to reboot system. Weapons officer is responsible. Captain was right about suspicions. Decide to not screw over crew.

Later, I'm learning how to be capitan on my own ship, the Damrey.

Sceince guy with no mic joins and is probably a noob, and is acting overly cheery.

Going along when power goes out. Engie reboots it.

Noob science is obvious culprit when he turns it off again and runs to captain's chair when we all go investigate.

Tell science if he wants to get kicked he should do it again. He does it again.

After this crew I got a drunk pilot and a weapons officer who played edgy music through his mic.

21454686.review:
If you like the idea of things like Artemis Bridge Simulator this is worth a go. Online play is a lot of fun. The community is small but I haven't had a problem finding a friendly crew whenever I've looked. It feels like a very good game if you have a small group of friends that like to play games together.

+Several ships to start with or capture (each with a unique internal setup)
+Plenty of ship upgrades to loot or buy and configure your ship to your liking
+Large map offers enough space to explore and have an extended adventure
+Ship to ship combat feels very good and involves all roles
+boarding enemy ships is very cool feature
+-Crew Bots are okay enough to play solo till you get a feel for the game, but need work to allow much more
-FPS combat feels barebones and not satisfying at the moment, but it works
-Planet maps (I've seen so far) are rather small and empty feeling
-Game is yet to be optimized, so performance issues at higher video settings were very noticable

I put this with Early Access games that are complete enough to be worth playing now even if further development is slow/doesn't happen (though I hope it does). This game fits a uique enough niche that I can overlook it's few flaws.

21270157.review:
With the right friends, this game really does seem like your own personal episode of Firefly or Star Trek.  
So, here's my take on this game.

The Captain ordered us to look for security drones.  We spent about 30 minutes on a search and destroy until we needed to head back and repair the hull.  I am the pilot and yes, I'm a girl.  My first attempt at docking with the repair station was ...sporty.  If you've ever seen the movie galaxy quest then you will have a good idea of what it's like to fit the destroyer into a repair station docking bay.  

Our first away mission resulted in our captain yelling "Oh sh*t!" and then promptly dying.  When asked what killed him, he said something "Ambiguous" and told us to head right when we exited the terraforming station.  I headed right and immediately died by the "Ambiguous" hostile who seemed intent on shoving a plasma cannon up my posterior.  I was very happy that someone had remembered to turn on the respawning platform on board the ship.  Except for the need to change my uniform, I was ready to beam back to the planet surface and return the favor.  

This game is all about friends and teamwork.  The better your team, the more fun you will have.  I wasn't happy with the price tag considering the state it's currently in but if you play this with a group of people who have a good sense of humor and a love for space operas, you will never regret the purchase.  I love this game and I see only good things to come because it's only going to get better from here.

21104845.review:
A space-RPG that is a mix between FTL, Guns of Icarus and quest based rpg. 

The game is fun, and the way to the official release shouldn't be long. That said, there are still bugs and glitches that has to be fixed and more depth to the game to be added. But the potential is there!

The game consists of several classes, all of which have their own tasks to make the spaceship run smoothly. They have upgradable talents that will give perks to either themselves or to the ship. 
The engineer has control of power usage and core temperature, along with the systems on the ship such as weapons, shield and warp drive. 
The pilot maneuvers the ship. The controls takes some minutes to get used to, but becomes easy after flying around for a little time. 
The weapon specialist fires the big gun. Probably the easiest positions, but also very entertaining. Railgun, laser turret, missiles, nukes and more. 
The scientist is more like an electronic warfare operator. Cyberwarfare (infecting enemy ship systems with computer viruses), shield boosting and programming, and scanning of planets and ships. 
The captain is the big boss. He is in control of buying and selling components and equipment for the ship, has full economical control and makes the plans for where to go and what to do. Personally I think this role is a bit dull, as it consists of mostly just telling people what to do, without doing anything yourself (except from plotting in the course in the starmap). This is realistic, of course, but still the position I like the least. 

A good crew can be really fun to play with, and you dont even have to be 5 to play. AI exists, but I haven't really figured them out, and initially i find them to be quite crap as opposed to a player. Another similarity with Guns of Icarus I guess. 

tldr; fun co-op game with space exploration and upgradable ship and characters. Crossover between FTL/Guns of Icarus/RPG.

20939757.review:
What a breath of fresh air! I haven't had this much fun playing a co-op game with people online in years.

My first time trying it  out I was on a small ship with one guy, neither of us having a clue what we were doing but we figured some things out enough to get somewhat comfortable with the basics of a couple of positions. Piloting the ship was straight-forward enough and so was manning the turrets. Time to look for a game with more people.

Next game I hopped in I was the pilot. Whenever I didn't know what to do the captain was kind enough to explain, and things were simple enough to learn. I played and learned with that full crew of 5 for about an hour.

Next game I was the gunner, also very simple to learn if you ever played any games in your life before, and I felt good being an important part of why we made it through fights with drones and other ships.

Engineer took a bit more of friendly people explaining what things did, but I found I didn't always have a lot to do so I continued asking questions so I would have some understanding of science and captain positions.

The next night I played a game as scientist and the crew had to explain a good number of things to me, but within an hour I had a full understanding of my duties and we played for 5 hours straight.
That's right. I played a co-op game with 4 strangers for 5 hours straight.
We explored planets, completed missions, applied talent points to improve or characters, collected scrap and upgrades and sold things we found to buy better ship components, and eventually boarded and stole a more powerful enemy ship by sheer planning, strategy, and team work.

I definitely got a strong Star Trek feel from the game, which was very much a good thing in my opinion, and in 2 days I felt like the game by far earned its price of admission, something so many early access games these games never do even up to completion.

The only downside was that the graphics are pretty dull overall even on highest settings.

9.5/10 for a teamwork based space co-op online game that is still in beta.

20931914.review:
Pulsar is a game about exploring planets and doing quests for money and xp to upgrade both your character and your ship.
There are 5 classes, here are the basics for each one;
Pilot: The pilot flies(obviously) the ship and can upgrade the ships performance as they level up
Scientist(my favorite): The scientist can heal other crewmates and during space combat, they can send various viruses(some are buffs for your own ship, some disable other ships systems,etc.) which can really turn the tide of the battle
Weapons Specialist: The weapons specialist is responsible for dishing out damage and is the only one able to use the main turret(unless you unlock the talent in another class) and they upgrade their guns(including their small arms) as the level
Engineer: Oh god, the engineer. The engineer is responsible for making sure the ship's core doesn't over heat, and can turn systems and such off and on to conserve power and keep the temp down. If the core overheats they have to eject the core before it explodes like a mini nuke! If your the engineer you have to know what your doing beforehand!
The Captain(My least played class): The Captain is the one who trades and buys/sells equipment for the crew. He also plots the course and which quests to go to. The captain is probably one of the most important classes in the game.
Finally, what i feel about this game! This game is an amazing game to play with a group of friends. The solo experience isn't all that great. The game's art style is done very well and the music is spot on. My only problems are that there can be the occasional bug where you see different loot and enemies in your instance the game, and I REALLY hope they make the planets more than just a small level, wish you could explore planets more, but other than those few things this is a GREAT game to play with friends!

I've downloaded this game first via some strange ways (also know as not-very-legal-versions). I wanted to try before buy, because I've problems with horror/suspense games (I was afraid this game was, but isn't not!).

Imagine Star Trek, without the Hollywood things. This is PULSAR. You can control your own ship, have friends or meet someone to help with your ship, land in planets to explore or complete missions (now you can research things from items you find in the planet).

PROS:
- The game is really fun.
- The graphic is not heavy but it's cool.
- The game dynamic is amazing, a lot of things to do, etc.
- Is a randomly-generated universe.
- A lot of people are noobie-friendly. Is not like the majority of multiplayer games who don't care about the newbies. I like it, since I'm always a newbie!

CONS:
- A mini-map inside a ship, like the carrier, will be great (really - it's huge and I usually get lost).
- It's in beta, so: bugs.
- There is a little big of lag.
- It would be great to have more team in the ship (up to 10 probably? Specially for ships with more than 1 gun).
- Some ships are extremely DARK. 
- Some people are bad and will damage your ship just because they can and nobody will know who the person was, except if caught in the act. A log system for the captain will be great.
