18218283.review:
So... Another early access.

People have described this by using references to other games, but I think that's unfair. It is a game in it's own right, I'll try to explain what it's about. If anything, playing this game feels like watching episodes of Star trek TOS and those types of references are readily used by players. Be my redshirt for a day.

You play as one out of five crewmen, each have their own class with unique talents (skills) that can be leveled up. The crew share level, which is a nice feature and works well for this co op game. You start of with an under powered ship, warp around to different sectors to engage enemies, navigate minefields, send away teams to planets and just do that whole trek thing. You can also get missions from NPC's on outposts.

So, if you like these things, maybe this is for you. I say maybe, because we are currently at beta 3 and the game is severily lacking in game content: the planets have very limited areas, model animations are missing, loads of enemies and locations missing and so on. There's not a whole lot to do yet.

That said, I like the premise and the game mechanics presented so far. The development team, although small, find the time to reply to forum posts (even on Steam!), fix issues and consider suggestions. If AAA-studios had HALF the customer service these guys do the gaming industry would be SO much better. If you are tired of buying early access games that are broken, has no dev communication and take forever to get updates, you might actually find that Leafy games is a fresh breath of air.

It's Unity 5, so it works pretty well on Linux. There are some optimization issues, but this early in development one cannot expect optimized graphics. In spite of being part of the Unity ghetto, Leafy games showcases that Unity games doesn't have to be unstable, GPU slaughtering beasts of C# nonsense. In particular on the Linuxes!

EDIT: there is one feature missing that everyone has been talking about, it is also probably the hardest thing to do. Right now it has network multiplayer, but only for up to 5 people of the crew and only one player ship per server. If we could get multiple player controller ships on the same server it would be amazing!

18203864.review:
Eine ganz neue Erfahrung! Das ist Immersion, Rollenspiel und Teamspiel in einer hervorragenden Kombination.
Sowas wie ein Artemis Space Sim (Ein Raumschiff-Brücken-Simulator) aber sehr viel virtueller in einem persistenten RPG Universum.

Das eigene Schiff sowie Stationen und Areale auf Planeten überirdisch wie unterirdisch samt Gebäuden können frei erkundet werden. Im Weltraum kann die Galaxie per Schiff frei durchreist werden. Es ist sehr abwechslungsreich gestaltet.

Es gibt Fraktionen, Mission und Shops. Man kann sich und sein Schiff per Skills-System, Player-Items und Schiffskomponenten verbessern. Fünf Spieler-Klassen (Person oder Bot) bedienen zusammen ein Schiff.
Als Pilot das Schiff zu fliegen ist auch per Joystick mit voller HOTAS Unterstützung möglich. Dann das Schiff ausrichten, vom Ingenieur das Warp-Triebwerk laden lassen und frei durch die Galaxie düsen. Sehr gut umgesetzt und frei von Ladesequenzen. 

Um schneller durch die Galaxie zu kommen gibt es Sprungtore samt Anwahl- und Achsausrichtung-Sequenz die dann auch frei zu durchreisen sind. Auf Planeten wie auch Stationen wird sich per Transporter gebeamt (Vorsicht EVA-Suit nicht vergessen, je nach Klima). Auf der Oberfläche von Planeten gibt es Orte mit neuen Items aus Missionen oder frei zu entdecken und hin und wieder auch mit feindlichen Wesen und Robotern. Wenn man gerade keinen EVA-Suit trägt kann per doppelt Leer-Taste tippen und halten ein Jet-pack aktiviert werden. :)

Das bereisen des Weltraums ist dann das Raumschiff-Brücken-Simulator Element in diesem Spiel.
Es gibt fünf Stationen im Schiff zu besetzen und es wird dann, wie auch wie bei allen Trekkies und Trekkern bekannt, durch eine Brücken-Crew ein Raumschiff kontrolliert gesteuert, gewartet und verteidigt. Auch die Geschütze des Schiffes können bemannt werden.

Im Raumkampf kann es durchaus passieren das man geentert wird. Gleiches gilt im Gegenzug für einen Selbst auch sodass man sich hierdurch sogar ein neues Schiff beschaffen kann. Hilft vor allem dann wenn das eigene Schiff gerade vor dem Kern-Bruch steht.

Es gibt jetzt schon so viel Inhalt und Potenzial davon ließen sich noch Seiten füllen, deshalb mein Fazit:

Dafür dass das Spiel noch Early-Access / Beta ist, läuft es sehr stabil und zuverlässig bei mir auf Linux.
Das was bisher schon an Inhalt und Funktionalität im Spiel implementiert ist lässt hoffen dass das finale Spiel seinen Weg beibehält. Alle diese Elemente und RPG-Funktionen zur Interaktion mit dem Schiff und mit NPCs an den verschiedenen Orten benötigen noch ein wenig mehr Tiefgang. Aber das Gameplay ist jetzt schon Phänomenal und macht auch mit Freunden im Voice-Chat eine menge Spaß! Zu empfehlen sind auch die Anleitungen auf der Webseite des Spiels selbst!

Schön ist auch das Multiplayer Konzept sodass frei im Singleplayer gespielt werden kann – das sich aber jederzeit während des Spiels aufheben lässt und andere Spieler per Password oder komplett Public herein zu lassen.

Ich finde das Spiel ist bisher eine gelungene Umsetzung und lässt in der finalen Version auf einen guten Abschluss hoffen.
Diese Kombination von Spiel-Elementen ist in dieser Form bisher einzigartig und vereint viele Elemente anderer Weltraumspiele hervorragen in sich.

18189178.review:
Hello dear astronauts!

When I saw the trailer of this game I was sold. It had all the good stuff! Space exploration, space ships, space battles, space ants/spiders/robots, and it had space itself. I started playing it, and I just couldn't stop. Started out joining a random game where someone taught me all the basics. And hell, there are a lot of basics! Learning the game is pretty overwhelming at first. Untill you have played all 4 support roles it is hard to be the captain. 

Thus, the day after the basics I decided to dedicate my day comandeering the U.S.S. Flying dutchman. I found some people, put them on a teamspeak and we played for about 8 hours straight. The experience was amazing! I lead us to planets, bandits, dronespaceships, and all there is to do. Everyone was immersed in their role, and achieving the goals I set for them. The one main problem we found out though was this. 
After 8 hours of playing the game, we had seen it all. We had beaten both bosses, seen the infected ( which you cant actually kill yet.), been to all exotic shops, upgraded all the gear on the ship untill there was no proper match for us anymore. It was lacking content, but I kept longing for more. 

Tl;Dr?

Pro's: 
-Awesome gameplay. You are free to do w/e you want.
-Game really promotes player interaction. You have to function as a team. No soloing here.
-It is very immersive. You get into your role and stick with it almost naturally. 

Cons:
-Some minor bugs. Server list not reloading, mines not blowing up, laser targetting messing up etc. 
-Severe lack of content though this will most probably be worked on by the dev team!
-The game will take you and make you play it till theres nothing left to play. (might actually be a good thing)
-Game is quite boring without actual voice chat. (might be different for you)

Final verdict: 
Buy this! But if you're patient enough, wait for a couple of months untill there is more content.

Ever watch Star Trek and say "I'd like to be one of the members on that ship"?

Well, this game will allow you the opportunity to do just that!!!

I have played thousands of games in my lifetime and I honestly can't say that I've enjoyed a game as much as this one in MANY years. I know the graphics look quite dated and it is true. This is not a game where you can expect to have everything glorified like you see in most new games out on the market. 

In a typical game you can start off pretty nice and relaxing at the controls and after a quick jump through space, your entire crew including yourself is thrown into a panic to man the guns and adjust power throughout the ship in order to ensure its survival. 

If you are a fan of star trek or have ever wanted to be part of that crew, do yourself a favor and get this game!!!
If you enjoy coop games where everyone on the crew has a specific job to take care of, get this game.

Cons to this game:

-dated graphics, 
-Some games will have too many chiefs and not enough indians which makes gameplay really not enjoyable.

All in all, find yourself a decent group of friends who are willing to teach you your job and let you at the controls no matter how often you may fail. This game is seriously under rated!!!!

18158460.review:
Rétissant à investir dans une Early access, j'ai fini par craquer en regardant les vidéos de EdgeMiles.
Conclusion: nous avons la un jeu qui s'approche du fantasme du geek  (dans le sens du terme en 1990).

Pourquoi vous devez investir dans se jeu:

Vous prenez place dans un équipage composé de 5 joueurs, 5 postes disponibles, dans un des 5 vaisseaux disponible:

    -Capitaine, c'est vous qui prendrez les décisions, et c'est également vous qui vous chargerez de vous occuper de la mise à niveau du vaisseau. Vous pourrez également accepter des missions dans les statio-ports, et gérer le commerce.
    -Ingénieur, vous aurez pour principale tâche de vous occuper du réacteur, de l'attribution d'énergie dans les différents éléments du vaisseau. C'est un des postes les plus crucial, il faut être réactif en cas d'urgence.
    -Scientifique, vous serez au commande du scanner, c'est donc vous qui tiendrez au courant l'équipage des différents éléments auquel vous serez confronté. Vous devriez également adapter la fréquence du bouclier en fonction du type d'armement adverse, et utiliserez les outils à votre disposition pour hacker, booster, et empecherez le hack de votre vaisseau.
    -Pilote, vous n'aurez qu'une tâche, c'est de manoeuvrer le vaisseau, faire en sorte que les armes on un angle de tir, tenter d'esquiver les attaques ennemis, aligner le vaisseau aux coordonnées...
    -Gunner, au commande de l'armement du vaisseau, vous serez le seul adpte à utiliser la plus grosse arme.

La cynergie entre les différents postes est tel qu'il faut constament communiquer. Beaucoup de joueurs se pretent bien au jeu et finissent par adopter le roleplay, ce qui renforce l'immersion et rend le tout excelent.

En parcourant la galaxie, vous tomberez sur des drônes, des vaisseaux ennemis, des manifestations naturels, vous aurez la possibilité d'effectuer des missions, de vous téléporter au sol ou sur les vaisseaux ennemis.
La difficulté augmentera au fur et a mesure que vous progresserez, il y a un véritable challenge.

Les devs sont particulièrement actif, à l'écoute des joueurs. De nombreuses features sont en chantier. 
Cependant en l'état actuel il y a déja de quoi s'éclater, c'est pourquoi je vous recommande cette Early, un excelent présent, un magnifique futur (je l'espère !).

18144240.review:
So... How to put this...
This is a freakin, AMAZING GAME.
Shall I simplify?
Nah I don't have to.
But I should.
Because it's awesome and you should know why if you haven't bought it already.
Which you should have.
Because its awesome.
Aaaaaaaanyway.

The graphics aren't great, but.. hey who cares? The gameplay rocks!
You have to work as a team or your ship will die, it has a very 'firefly, star trek, galaxy quest' style of gameplay where you all choose roles etc. I was the weapons specialist and my job was to fire big guns and be the away team, so essentially what you'd call a red shirt.
I always died.

The cons:
Well, it's beta, so there are a few bugs, and the diversity of equipment is low.
But that's all I found to gripe about.

In my first two hours, I:
Beamed down onto a lava planet in my exosuit with the crew and killed a bunch of slugs in some caves.
Went to numerous desert planets and icy planets.
Saw my Captain get swollowed up by some giant worm like thing.
Got eaten by a bunch of large ants whilst exploring some old ruins.
Blew up an enemy ship whilst my captain was aboard.
Got shot by some robot thingy.
And developed an unnatural fondness with the nuke we had on board the ship.

What a misfit crew we made.

So.... Essentially this game has been one of the most enjoyable games I have played of late; having found myself bored with games and desperately looking for some relief... This, this is the game. And in the first two hours I have done so much, bonded with the crew. It truly is one of the best games on steam, and is very worth the amount of money it costs. The development team listens closely to it's fans and is very active. I was following their youtube channel for a year keeping up with the dev logs.

Basically, buy it. If you like team based, explorative sci fi games that have the potential to create fun stories and scenarios, this is the game for you.

18141546.review:
Pulsar Lost Colony has a strong foundation but is generally empty and shallow compared to what they're claiming should be in the game at this point.

Now don't get wrong, it's not a terrible game - but it's definitely at this point not worth the 25.00 you pay for it.

The AI is completely broken still, you're incapable of capturing multiple ships and there's a LOT of bugs with creatures/npc's/stations/bases.

As well the game is extremely repetitive and the majority of planets you visit are copy pasted. In the three hours I played I visited 4 desert planets and 3 frozen planets - all of which with repeated terrain and base layouts.

The combat is also the same each and every fight - you circle your opponent and shoot them until one of you dies. 

Boarding is pointless - since you cant have multiple ships there's really no point to ever going onto the enemy ship. Upgrades are fairly easy to get within the first hour of the game, so that is also an issue.

Overall it's not a great game - I'd give it a 5 - as of right now it needs a lot of work and I would not suggest buying it for 25 dollars.

Sorry!

18091178.review:
This game is reminicent of FTL, but does plenty to differentiate itself from FTL.  It's in 3D and has 5 man online co-op featuring 5 unique roles: a Captain, a Scientist, an Engineer, a Pilot, and a Weapon's Specialist! Each role has it's own bonuses, a rudimentary skill tree, and different things to do such as steering the ship, hacking/scanning, manning turrets, fixing the ship or bossing people around. 

I've had some great moments in this game. As the engineer, there's nothing quite like pulling off Scotty like miracle work and saving the ship with last second engine repairs and then punching the button that jumps you all to safety. Similarly when there's a virus in the computer, rebooting the computer involves some Jurassic Park style flipping of big switches that always makes me chuckle to myself every time I see them! They're great. As the pilot I got to show off my piloting skills while gingerly easing the ship through the tight passages of an ancient wrecked structure and navigating around dangerous mines as we tried to salvage some loot. As the weapons specialist there was a moment when we bit off more than we could chew, with our ship blazing, and our weapons knocked offline I made a snap decision to board the enemy ship at the last second and managed to destroy their weapons, haulting incoming damage just long enough for my crewmates to jump the ship to safety. As the captain the first adventure was a blast, with me totally clueless but leading a crew of seasoned veterans, and they just rolled with it, bless them. It was a disaster, but everyone had fun. The scientist is the most underapreciated role, but they have their uses such as scanning for lifeforms and modulating shields. Although underappreciated, I take secret pleasure in joining a game as the scientist. I've heard rumours that there will be some form of scientific research added at a later date to flesh out the role a little more, and I do hope so.

You can do some similar things in Pulsar that you can do in FTL such as boarding enemy ships, targetting their subsystems, hacking, shutting off their oxygen (or your own), causing/putting out fires, shopping, and upgrading your ship. There are some things you can do in pulsar that you can't do in FTL such as beaming down to planets, visiting space stations, comandeering enemy ships. There are some really nice touches, such as when you grab cargo, that stuff starts appearing on cargo pads in your ship. So when your ship fills up with cargo, it literally does fill up with cargo. Really adds to the immersion.

The galaxy is open world which to me is a huge plus, so there's a lot of freedom to roam the galaxy as your captain pleases. The open world doesn't extend to planets, with surface areas being small areas around the teleporter pad, more akin to dungeons than planet surfaces. But they are certainly functional enough for their purpose.

If you're lookng for something to play at the weekends with friends then there is definitely a lot of fun to be found here. Get 4 friends wth you and hilarity ensues. It was watching a live steam of people playing this that made me instantly buy it!

If you're looking for an FTL-like game you can follow the development of and play occasionally when patches come out then this is a good buy. Judging from their past dev-videos, new content comes approximately on a monthly basis with bugfixes and tweaks more regularly. If you like the concept and are willing to support a dev on the potential of their game alone then you will probably not be disappointed, Personally, I played pulsar for 2 days solid, and stopped playing it, only because I don't want to play it to death at this early stage. I know there is still a lot of content needs to be added and so it's better to only dabble in it for now. So now I just play it for a bit when patches some out.  The base game is complete, and all the core mechanics have been fleshed out to where it's a fully fledged game. There is a large galaxy to explore and missions you can play through. All that is lacking is a decent variety of content to keep things interesting in the long run. To be sure if you're looking for something that you can play all day long, every day, and never run out of content, then this is not the game for you--at least not yet. But if you're looking for something to dabble in until the developer has a chance to flesh it out more then I heartilly recommend.

As with all Early Access games there's no guarentee it will ever be finished, So really it comes down to whether you're willing to support the developer on the merit of what they have right now and on the future potential. Keep in mind your idea of "fleshed out" might differ from the developers. I've been burned before, *cough* Elite Dangerous *cough*. But I still see it as worth the risk to support smaller devs such as this when they have something that really appeals to me. If you're not sure then check out youtube, or better yet wait till release and you'll know for sure.

18082742.review:
This review will be in english and in french. I'll start with the english one.
Cette évaluation sera en anglais et en français. Je commence par l'anglais.


[u][b]Graphics[/b][/u]

This game is very far from what we are used to in recent or upcoming games like Mad Max, Fallout, or Star Citizen (if we want to stay in the same game spirit). 
You should not expect some amazing visuals in this game. However, the design of the ships, of the HUBs, and of structures on planets can easily make you forget the flaws if you like space operas like I do.
And even if you don't, there is something else that can get your attention : the possibilities in the gameplay.


[u][b]Gameplay[/b][/u]

I only played for about 7h at the time I'm writing this. However, I also spent a lot of time reading the manual for every role (quite useful for anyone who wants to be Captain, as you can learn all you need to know to give correct orders to your crew).
But I was absolutely amazed by how good the game system is. It's both complex and really simple. Complex because you need a slightly capable crew and a good captain in command to push your ship to its limits and discover all the possibilities the game offers. And simple because every panel speaks for itself and is understandable to anyone with at least 80 I.Q. The difficult part is to coordinate everyone.

Because it really is a coop game. With your friends or with stranger, you will need a good communication if you don't want to see your core explode your ship because your engineer forgot to apply the coolant liquid in the middle of a furious fight with a drone. Yeah, that can happen, trust me.
There is the possibility to play alone, with AI Bots in place of the different roles, but it's really not the same. And the Bots are still a work in progress and are not always responding as you'd expect. 
A good thing is, there's a small but nice community of players and an "official" teamspeak if you want to quickly find a crew and easily communicate with them.


[u][b]What's in the game yet ?[/b][/u]

Right now, you have several missions available, 5 different ships with differents components, weapons and internal configuration, a trade system for your ship at every station, few merchants in the main HUB to purchase better weapons or tools, the possibility to explore some planets, 5 very specific roles to control your ship and even more ...
Remember this is still an early access, but it already has a buttload of stuff to do and discover.


[u][b]All of that in two sentences ?[/b][/u]

It's a better Star Trek game than any Star Trek game. It's really about managing your ship and going on an adventure, half simulation, half adventure game. The devs take care of the bugs as soon as they know there are some, there is already tons of content and even more scheduled in the next year, and if you like space opera and have some friends, this is what you need.

Graphics : 6/10
Gameplay : 9.5/10 (It's awesome, but nothing is perfect)
Content already in game : 8/10
Content scheduled : 9/10
Devs communication and reactivity + update frequency : 9/10

Overall quality : 8.5/10 But I expect it to go at 9.5 after a fiew more updates.



Bien, passons maintenant à la review française.

[u][b]Graphismes[/b][/u]

Ce jeu est très très loin de la qualité graphique que l'on trouve dans des jeux actuels ou à venir tels que Mad Max, Fallout ou encore Star Citizen (puisqu'on est dans le space opera).
Ne vous attendez donc pas à des graphismes d'une qualité hallucinante. Cependant, le design des vaisseaux, des stations et même des structures planétaires permet d'oublier tout ça, en particulier si vous aimez le genre.
Et même si ce n'est pas le cas, vous pourrez être séduit par les possibilités laissées par le gameplay.


[u][b]Gameplay[/b][/u]

Au moment où j'écris, je n'ai que 7 heures de jeu derrière moi. Cependant, j'ai passé un certain temps à étudier les sytèmes et à lire l'intégralité des manuels présents sur le site (très utile si vous incarnez le Capitaine et voulez connaitre les systèmes à votre disposition).
Et j'ai été très impressionné de la qualité globale du système de jeu. A la fois complexe et simple d'accès. 
D'abord complexe parce que vous aurez besoin d'un équipage réactif et d'un capitaine compétent pour pouvoir pousser votre vaisseau à ses limites et découvrir tout ce qu'il a à offrir. Et en même temps simple car chaque panneau de contrôle est relativement clair et peut être compris par n'importe qui. La vraie difficulté est de coordonner l'équipage.

Car c'est bel et bien un jeu de coopération. Que ce soit avec des amis ou avec des inconnus, vous aurez besoin d'un bonne communication si vous ne voulez pas que votre réacteur surchauffe et vous explose dans les mains parce que votre ingénieur n'avais pas appliqué le liquide de refroidissement. Oui, ça arrive, croyez moi.
Il y a la possibilité de jouer tout seul, en plaçant des bots aux différents postes, mais l'expérience n'est pas du tout la même. D'autant plus que les bots ne sont pas encore complètement au point et ne font pas toujours ce que vous attendez d'eux.
Vous pourrez voir qu'il y a déjà une petite communauté sympathique, ainsi qu'un teamspeak plus ou moins officiel qui permet de trouver rapidement un équipage et de communiquer efficacement.


[u][b]Qu'est-ce qu'on peut faire dans le jeu pour l'instant ?[/b][/u]

A l'heure acutelle, il y a plusieurs missions disponibles, 5 vaisseaux très différents au niveau des composants, de l'armement et de la configuration interne, un système de commerce pour le vaisseau à chaque station, plusieurs marchands dans le HUB principal permettant d'ameliorer vos blasters et outils de réparation, 5 rôles différents et complémentaires, la possibilité d'explorer quelques planètes, et encore bien d'autres choses surprenantes ...
Souvenez vous qu'il s'agit d'un accès anticipé, mais qu'il y a déjà beaucoup à faire et à découvrir.


[u][b]Tout ça résumé en trois mots ?[/b][/u]

C'est un meilleur jeu Star Trek que n'importe quel jeu Star Trek. Vous gérez vraiment votre vaisseau, à mi-chemin entre la simulation et l'aventure.
Les développeurs sont très réactifs concernant les bugs, et en plus du large contenu déjà présent, encore plus est prévu au cours de l'année à venir.
Si vous aimez les space operas et que vous avez quelques amis partants, ce jeu est fait pour vous.

Graphismes : 6/10
Gameplay : 9.5/10
Contenu déjà présent : 8/10
Contenu prévu : 9/10
Réactivité et communication des développeurs + fréquence des updates : 9/10

Qualité générale : 8.5/10 Mais je monterai certainement à 9.5 après quelques updates.

So firstly the Dev's of this game are insanely detected about this.

Open-world Space & Planet exploration game, 5 player co-op, you'd think that'd require a huge development team.
Nope, not only have the guys at Leafy Dev's done this on their own but they've done it well!

Still in Beta and there's already a ton of stories me and my friends are able to share back and fourth about our exploits, which are often made even more special because we experienced this together, and together having to essentialy synchronize as a team, so when we earned something we damn well earned it!

18077004.review:
I'm skeptical about this game. It's in early access, which never really fills me with hope. However, from what I've seen so far, it shows a great deal of promise (which could be said for other games, really) and the developers are working tirelessly with the playerbase to stabilise and improve the game.
The game itself is an interesting concept. 5 players, each with their own role, working together in order to complete missions. Already it sounds like a number of games, but the way that Pulsar does this is not quite what you'd expect (unless you happen to expect something along the lines of guns of spacearus). Bots are available, but I'm writing this review with a Co-op impression in mind. 
These 5 players are given a Spaceship and a role aboard it. Then, they're left to their own devices. The Galaxy is open to them from T minus 0, and there's quite a wealth of things to do. I recommend finding out firsthand. The game doesn't ease the player in very much. They are briefed on their role, but I learned quickly when I had someone talk me over the ship in a couple of minutes. Of course, there is some reading material that you could make use of.
The game doesn't hold your hand. The further out you go, the harder things are going to get. Work with your team and you can overcome all. Surely, this game has a thing for improving communication and building cohesion, However, I recommend a clear medium of communication, such as a Vent, person-person proximity, Teamspeak, and so on. As far as I am aware, there is no in-game VoIP. The options aren't great, and you may have an issue running the game. It's on Unity, I think.
I wish I could rate things out of 10 easily, but I don't really think that way. I think you could describe the entire game, so far, as Guns of Spacearus Online, the PVE sandpaign.

18076188.review:
[h1]Introduction[/h1]

[b]Think FTL but in first person, with other people![/b]

Pulsar: Lost Colony is a space combat/exploration game that recently entered early access. In Pulsar you take control of a spacecraft with a crew of five humans/bots and with this spacecraft you explore a huge galaxy filled with danger. As you take on, and hopefully destroy, enemies you’ll be awarded with credits which can be spent on upgrades for your craft to make it far more effective. Pulsar also allows you to send away teams onto planets to search for items, lifeforms and everything in-between.

I won’t explain what the different classes in the game do but I will talk about them in my review so if you wish to know more about the classes look at the Overview in the Manual: http://www.pulsarthegame.com/manual/

[h1]Presentation[/h1]

First up, the overall appearance of the game; it’s by no means the best looking game going but the graphical style definitely fits with the game, particularly for the ships, so I can’t fault it here. The ships themselves look absolutely fantastic, both inside and out. The character models and a few of the textures on the planets are a leaning towards the not so great side of things but this can be forgiven since you don’t spend too much time looking at either since most of the time in game is spent keeping the ship working during combat. The main menu is simple and gets the job done, not much to say here. Apart from the chat window there’s not really a UI in the game but the space craft’s ship displays are the equivalent here. The displays are what you spend most of your time looking at if you play as an engineer or a scientist but they’re also important to the other classes. They’re all done very well as they’re simple and easy to use. The one for engineering is particularly good as it’s just sliders and toggle buttons and engineers need to change things quickly.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

Pulsar lets you choose from one of five (currently) ships, each with its own stats, advantages, disadvantages etc. Once you’ve selected your ship and you’ve assembled your crew you can either take and complete missions or you can just go off exploring in the randomly generated galaxy. I spent most of my time just travelling around the galaxy randomly, i.e. without trying to complete missions, and it felt rather similar to FTL. The Captain of your ship sets a course for you and then the pilot (human or AI) has to line the ship up with the system you’re travelling to so the engineer can trigger a jump to that system. 

Arriving in a system can lead to any of the following situations: combat with one or more basic enemies, combat with a ‘boss’, the discovery of a trading post/repair depot, the discovery of a planet which can be explored or the discovery of empty space. More often than not you find yourself in the first situation so I’ll go ahead and explain how combat works. Depending on which ship you choose you’ll have a number of different weapons available to you, all of which can either be controlled by different players or can be controlled by the WeaponBot. Your weapons can only be used a certain number of times before needing to recharge, how long this recharge time is depends on what weapon it is and how much power you’ve diverted to weaponry. The recharge times are generally rather long and this is my first major issue with the gameplay since it makes combat feel rather slow whereas, in my opinion, it should be much faster paced. Enemy ships can also be boarded once a certain amount of their shields have gone down, boarding a ship allows you to kill its crew and then take over the ship or just destroy its systems.

[h1]AI[/h1]

Pulsar: Lost Colony is meant to be played by five real people and it shows in the quality of the currently implemented bots. Firstly, due to the nature of the bots, it’s almost impossible to run a ship with only one human player so if you’re planning to get the game, make sure you find some people to play with. However, it is possible to play with 2+ players quite comfortably, having a captain and engineer as humans and the rest as bots is effective without overworking the humans. The reason I suggest this setup is because the weapon and pilot bots seem to be as good if not better than human players at those jobs as they’re easier to automate. The devs do plan to improve the bots later in development so hopefully things while improve.

[h1]Physics[/h1]

Pulsar has several issues with physics in the game, I don’t know how realistic the devs want this game to be so perhaps these issues are in fact not issues at all but I’ll list them anyway. Of course I don’t expect them to have super realistic physics in the game but something less non-realistic would be nice.
[list]
[*]Once you stop firing the ship’s thrusters it gradually comes to a stop, since space is a vacuum there’s no resistance hence you should remain at the same speed as when you stopped firing the thrusters.
[*]Planets have no gravitational pull on your ship.
[*]Some of the larger ship guns, have ridiculously large amounts of recoil, obviously there should be some force coming back from the shot (Newton’s Third Law if you’re interested) but significantly spinning the ship is over the top.
[/list]

[h1]Miscellaneous[/h1]
[list]
[*]The audio is great in the game, the sounds that the ship makes are particularly good
[*]There are already a few customisation options for you character including gender, hair style, hair colour and eye colour etc.
[*]Personally I think the asking price is a little steep for Early Access but if you’re willing to pay a little extra than you’d expect and you know people to play with then I’d say it’s still worth it.
[*]The devs seem very proactive when it comes to fixing bugs which are reported in the forum which is really good to see for an Early Access game.
[*]It’s not beginner friendly at all, the manual doesn’t go into too much detail and it doesn’t really tell you how to actually operate the ship, Pulsar would definitely benefit from a proper tutorial.
[/list]

[h1]Verdict[/h1]

[b]Worth Purchasing.[/b]

Pulsar: Lost Colony is a great co-op space combat game with a vast, randomly generated galaxy, several ships to choose from and fun, if not a little slow, combat. If you’ve always wanted a  co-op version of FTL, or if you’re just looking to scratch a space game itch, Pulsar may just be the game for you.

[b]Review Copy Provided.[/b]

[i]No drama, [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/justreviews]Just Reviews.[/url][/i]

El K.

Star Trek Fan ist, was man sich kaufen kann. Der Anfang ist etwas friemelig, aber wenn man die Basics verstanden hat, dann steht der Eroberung des Weltalls nichts mehr im Wege. Grafik ist gut, Performance ist super. Ab und an gibt es Bugs, wie z.B. ein Jumpdrive der nicht lädt, oder Gegner die nicht angreifen und nicht angegriffen werden können. Der Schwierigkeitsgrad ist anfänglich sehr hoch, so kann es sein, das man z.B. direkt nach dem Spawn bereits von Dronen angegriffen und zerstört wird, oder das Schiff die 2. Begegnung im nächsten Sektor mit gegnern nicht übersteht. Nach der eingewöhnung ist es dann allerdings das coolste Space Game was ich zur Zeit oder bislang je gespielt habe. 

Das Erkunden von Planeten, Annehmen von Aufgaben ect. funktioniert. Eine riesen Galaxie mit aberhunderten Systemen wartet auf Exploration. 

Den meisten Spass hat man sicher, wenn man das Game statt mit AI Bots mit seinen Freunden zusammen spielt. Definitf eine Reise Wert und auf jeden Fall unterstützenswert!

18071563.review:
Five astronauts! One spaceship. Infinite possibilities? 
 
If you ever wanted to control a spaceship together with 4 other real players, this might be the game for you. The flight controls, engines and subsystems are all operated from computer terminals, located on the bridge and other places inside the ship. Players must coordinate their actions to effectively repel enemies or even jump from one sector to the next. While it's the Captains job to take over this coordination (and drink coffee), the Pilot controls the movement, the Weapon Specialist operates the gun turrents, the Scientist the ships software and scanners and the Engineer watches over the energy usage and temperature of the core.  
 
Gameplay example: If you need your weapons to reload faster, the Engineer can switch of systems like internal lights and air conditioning to reroute more power to the weapons or he may switch of shields to have even more power available. The Scientist can temporally boost certain systems with his programs or he can try to hack the enemy ships systems. Of course you can't use all systems on full power at all times, since your ships core will heat up dangerously. Gameplay is often described as Faster Than Light in 3D and Coop. 
 
You can board enemy ships and fight AI crews, explore planets, loot candy and go shopping in space stations. On your travels you will find scrap to sell or ship parts to instal. It's important to plan a route that passes by repair stations to repair the hull or upgrade with new parts. Also you want to stock up on fuel, missiles and coolant fluid used to cool the core in the heat of battle.
 
At the moment there are 5 ships to choose from, all different in size and layout. They all have beautiful lounges to relax and one even has a bar. 10/10 points for that alone. 
 
In the end of the day it's a very fun coop-experience, you want to share with a group of good friends OR the very nice community. 
 
In future I would love to see more things to do onboard except operation the ship. How about some mini games to pass the idle time (btw: there is no idle time, if you don't want. You can jump into action in less than a minute) or enable Roleplay.

This game is astounding. I've been playing this game for as long as it's been available to the public, and you cannot believe how happy I get whenever I see a new devlog. The community is amazing. This game is amazing! It's a multi palyer crew spaceship sim. Basically what Star citizen is going to be jsut on a lower graphical scale.

Currently it's in alpha and feels like it. A good portian of the mechanices are still not implemented and there is no tutorial. The only way to learn how to play and what's in and what's not is to open the menu and click View manual.

Basically when you first join the server you pick your role: Captain, Pilot, Scientist, Weapons Specialist and Engineer

The Capt. Pulls all the info from everyone together and tells everyone what to do (this person should know how to play, they should be ableto guide the others) The capt also buys and sell stuff and is more or less in control of the money.

The Pilot, moves the ship. To warp he has to line up up the ship and the engineeer has to press a button. The pilot doesn't.

The Weapons Sepc. Shoots the gun (and main gun).

The scientist has the best job in my opinion. They send viruses to enamy ships, they clean the system of viruses, they scan everything, the look up info on verious stuff and run good programs to boost shields give more thrusters ect.

The Engineer has the hardest job and in my opinion the 2nd best job. They have to prep for ward, balance the power core temp, turn the power on and off, and provide a boost to the scientist. You may not THINK thats a lot but when everone else uses there stuff it messes with your temp.

There are diffrent parts ofthe ship that can be damaged and needs repaired to keep that part going.

It feels a lot like guns of icurus but in space.

Like i said before; currently there is a lot missing of the game. but from whats not working, this game is going to be awesome!

18053327.review:
An intriguing little game with lots of ambition. It aims to be a glorious mashup of Artemis: Spaceship Bridge Sim, FTL, Guns of Icarus, and Star Trek: Away Team, and while it is admittedly a little light on content at the moment, it does a great job of capturing the essential components and atmospheres of all these games.

Players get to choose between four different ships to fly in, each with their own advantages and disadvantages, and five classes to play as: captain, pilot, weapons, engineering, and science, each with their own disticnt roles and RPG-style progression trees. At present, you start at The Hub, an expansive space station from which you can purchase items, weapons, and ship components, and also pick up various missions that drive progression in the game. Gameplay involves FTL-esque flight between randomized sectors, replete with derelict ships, crazed security bots, and enemy capital ships. There's also Away Team segments, where you can teleport down to nearby planets to fight the aliens de jour and search for your mission objectives. There are some neat metagame mechanics at work too: factions, reputation, and a Galactic Chaos system that ramps up the difficulty of enemies as you play. Apparently there are also some other surprises in store further out in the galaxy, but I haven't made it far enough out without getting vapourized to encounter them.

All in all, it's a super promising little title with great atmosphere and ambition that's just a little short on polish and content at time of writing, but is still a blast to play. Best played with friends! You can yell at each other to charge the warp core as you are torn apart by AI bots. 

Overal Verdict: Pre-Beard Riker -- full of potential, and just waiting to fill out into a space-age icon.

18050160.review: An excellent starship simulator where you can take on the role of the captin, pilot, engineer, weapons specialist, or science officer and work together with friends or AI bots to explore the galaxy, fight against evil corporations, or an unknown plague. 18050155.review:
- This review was written as of Beta 2, during Early Access -

PULSAR: Lost Colony is a game similar to Artemis or Quintet, where you and your friends take command of a single starship and do battle with enemies. However, instead of flying around a single sector, there's an entire galaxy out there to explore with factions, hostile aliens, and several missions to give you and your buddies some direction. 

Choose between one of five ships, and if you don't happen to like one, go ahead and board a ship of another type and take it for yourself! Upgrade your ship from parts of destroyed vessels or go on an away mission to a planet and look for salvage. There's something out there though, as my buddies and I explored we noticed some kind of infection sweeping over the galaxy and taking over as the literal chaos level increased. We haven't actually encountered it yet, but I read about alien monstrosities burrowing through the hull and attacking us from within.

It's Early Access Beta, and while the majority of the content isn't in the game yet, most of the core of the game is complete. Visit and walk around on space stations! Board enemy ships and capture them! Go planetside and search for relics, aliens, and clues to the titular Lost Colony! Go up in flames as your ship burns! Load the Nukes and pay them back with your dying breath! Boldly go wherever the hell you want with your only guide being how many credits you have left to gas up your tank, and your four buddies who might want to see what's JUST around the next bend - to blast it, analyze it, or turn it's leftover clink into some drink at the bar.

Early Access, yeah, I'm familiar with it. But I don't regret a thing this time, and I don't think you will either. This is the first best chance for a cooperative starship simulator in... ever. Throw some money at it, fund development, and get you some. 

And hey, if you don't see any potential in it after you've had a look - steam refunds exist, so I say grab your friends and give it a shot.

RECOMMENDED.

18048256.review:
[DISCLAIMER]: Everything I say here is of MY opinion. Don't get all mad because it doesn't allign with your opinion.

I have been following this game since it first came out on greenlight. This was around the time I still played Artemis: Spaceship Bridge Simulator and what this game promised was that game, but ten billion times better. First person ship bridge simulator is exactly what I wanted and I'm happy to say, this game delivers like there is no tomorrow.

The game like I said is a first person multiplayer spaceship exploration/combat simulator. I first got the game when it was in early alpha and even though it was very rough, the game still had tons of features and charm. You and perferably 4 other friends begin their journey on one of the five ships avaible (ATM) each with its own personal style of play and interior/exterior looks. One of the things I was really looking for in this kind of game was ship system interaction. By this I mean as a player I control the ship in anyway I want. Its not just go forward and back, shoot weapons, and so on, I can control where the power goes around the ship, I can scan the sector for enemies, I can use programs that boost stats or viruses that infect enemy computer, I can tweak what subsystem need power from lights to atmospherics. The goal of the game is go through this procedurally generated galaxy and kill enemies for scrap. Once you do so you buy upgrades at shops and equip them on your ship. After this you will eventually be powerful enough to take on the galaxy boss and claim victory. On the way to this main goal there is so much to do and see so lets go over some of that.

Things to do:
1. Kill enemies.
2. Loot abondoned space stations and structures for scrap all while avoiding dangerous mines.
3. Find a high class enemy ship and prepare to board!
4. Kill everything last thing on this enemy ship and hack is subsystems to take control of it!
5. Use your new sexy ship to fly to a planet.
6. Use your teleporter and beam down to the surface.
7. Don't forget your space suit because humans need oxygen.
8. Explore abondoned strucutes on the surface for food, weapons, collectables, and more!
9. Tell your friend to walk out into the desert by himself/herself but DONT tell him/her about the evil sand worm.
10. Find sector 0 and enter the famous Colonial Hub and meet new people and accept quests!
11. Get lost in the Colonial Hub
12. Fly into a sector with either a high level enemy or many enemies
13. Panic because you shields are down
14. REALLY panic because your ship is blaring its sirens and there are lots of red lights and evERYTHING IS SHAKING OH GOD
15. Die
16. Return more motivated than ever.
16. Pay taxes to use the Long Range Warp Station to move around faster.
17. Spend skill points to make yourself and your kick-ass crew even better!
18. Customize your apperance.
19. Try to overthrow the captain.
20. Fail at mutany
21. Get ingrossed in something and forget about the heat level of your reactor.
22. Panic AGAIN because all your system turned off due to emergency cooling.
23. Wonder what this switch does and eject your loving core out into space (What did it ever do to you!?)
24. Run out of fuel and have to open up your emergency broadcast beacon.
25. Pray to the space whales that someone nice will come to your aid.
26. Die from someone not so nice.
27. Get determined to win the game (or at least progress as far as you can in the games current state)
28. Do the process all again but not die
29. Get hype for you epic finale boss.
30. Pump your epic music so that your parents get annoyed.
31. Shoot the crap out of the boss using your skills and that handy dandy nuke you forgot about.
32. Revel in your victory and attempt to self destruct the ship.
33. Die
34. Give this game a thumbs up on Steam because of how awesome it is!

What I covered about is not all that you can do. Its an open world space game so you can make up stories, role play, and gather your buddies for a awesome LAN party thats not actually LAN because the game doesn't have that feature yet BUT it will. Anyways this game is great on almost all sides. I didn't even mention it but the art style is very clean but detailed and easy to look at. All in all I can give this game tons of my love and I think you should too! If your reading this and you know you could even slightly enjoy this game then you should really click that buy button. Lastly the devs to this game are super open about their development and are awesome dudes. They would love to help you with problems and so would the Pulsar community. The devs even have had polling sessions to vote on content that will be in the game! So buy the game or don't, if you don't your missing out on the best open world spaceship bridge simulator to date.

If you would like to see more I have a series of the game where me and some friend try our best to plow to the final boss. I will put a link to the first episode if you want to watch it. If not then don't, this isn't ment to be some plug or whatever but if you must think that it is, then i'm shamless about it :) Take care.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5kWIOClo4jg

18048011.review:
This is a brilliant game, you are part of a crew of 5 on a space ship, you can play with real players or with bots. When you're playing you're not just pressing E (or in this case R) on a console and that automatically cools the core, you need to lower that power usage or turn on the coolant (or both). Are the programs out of charge? Get your butt in engineering, load that fuel cell, and pull that lever. Want to know what that enemy ship has, scan it and see its power usage, components, status, and what type of ship it is.

You play as one of five roles, The Captain, The Pilot, The Weapons Specialist, The Engineer, and The Scientist.
[list]
[*]The Captain is self-explanatory, they orders the crew around, and is in charge of trading, diplomacy, that sort of stuff.
[*]The Pilot is also obvious, they pilot the ship, evade, align the ship, and give weapons a clear shot.
[*]The Weapons Specialist is usually controlling a massive super cannon, which is fires powerful lasers and missiles.
[*]The Engineer keeps the ship cool while at the same time giving everyone else enough power to work with.
[*]The Scientist will perform research, cyber warfare, scanning, and is generally the go to guy for getting to know what's going on.

You explore though space, teleporting onto stations, exploring planets, and trying to find the Lost Colony.

The website probably explains it better than so here [url=http://www.pulsarthegame.com]Link to website[/url]




tl;dr version: Starship simulator when those buttons actually have a purpose.

18047115.review:
PROS: Very cool concept(would love to see more of this style of game). Good devs. Lots of potential. It is funny how easily random people who join your crew can get into their roles both in terms of mechanics and role playing. The Captain is usually treated as the Captain and so on. There is a large galaxy to explore. Upgrading your ship and crew skills adds some sense of progression.

CONS: The content in the game is quite limited at the moment(though there is enough to sink your teeth into). The graphics are basic but it still has a decent aesthetic.

I look forward to the eventual fleshing out of ship's systems, crew abilities, AI interactions, missions, and planetary exploration. Like I said there is a lot of potential and a lot of features that can be added.

At around 17 hours I feel I have gotten my money's worth so anything extra is just icing on the cake.

18046695.review:
[h1]Update for Beta 1.5[/h1]

For original review, see below.

Half a year since I first played the game, I can say I'm largely disappointed. There have been 5 updates, of which 2 were advertised as 'major'. None of them addressed the issues that have been pointed by the community. The idea is still there, and there certainly have been improvements- however the game still fails to provide enough value for its' cost.

A good indicator of how PULSAR fails to keep people interested, even those that were initially excited about it, is the average playtime of the reviewers. 
Its' bad retention rate can also be assumed from the very low number of average and peak concurrent players (http://steamcharts.com/app/252870#All)

I'll certainly keep an eye on it, and hope it will sometime fulfill its' potential, but at its' current state, price and rate of improvement, I wouldn't recommend purchasing it.


[h1]Beta 1.2 preview[/h1]

Pulsar: Lost Colony is a very unique game. It draws heavy inspiration from genre-defining classics such as Star Trek and Firefly, and tries to provide a similar gaming experience, better than any game has so far managed to do. Its' mechanics might seem overly complex or even chaotic at first (and the lack of a tutorial doesn't help), but it doesn't take that long before getting used to how everything works.  

[b]Gameplay[/b]
A large portion of the gameplay consists of operating your ship through the use of monitors, flips and switches, controlling functions such as energy flow, offensive/defensive software, core temperature etc. Even though the UI can look archaic and out-of-place for an intergalactic spaceship, these monitors succeed in creating immersive and sometimes even frantic gameplay that rewards fast decision-making and combat awareness. 
Another imporant aspect of Pulsar's gameplay is the ability to leave your spaceship, either to board enemy ships (for a manlier offensive approach) or to explore planets and outposts. Even though the concept is there, the excitement you get from visiting planets is doomed to be on a progressive decline immediately after the first few expeditions, since the ecosystems and architectures available are extremely limited at this point, and most planets' explorable zones are far too small and generic to be jaw-dropping. One can assume, though, that this is an issue that's going to be adressed sooner or later, as more content is being added, resulting in more randomly generated variations and hopefully more non-random, unique planets and outposts. Boarding enemy ships is also quite enjoyable, and allows you to steal initially unavailable spaceships.
Other parts of the experience Pulsar has to offer include piloting, manning turrets, trading parts to upgrade your ship, using public restrooms, turning interior lights on and off (for a superb rave party experience), isolating yourself in the captain's cabin as well as a currently lackluster quest system.

[b]Classes[/b]
Role assignment is handled through five classes, each with its' own perks (available through leveling-up). The Captain controls the flow of the game and commands the crew, the Pilot steers the ship, the Engineer is responsible for the energy management, the Scientist ..uses software and the Weapons guy mans the turrets. Roles are fluid and can dynamically change during engagements, thus requiring effective communication between crew members, as is always the case with these kind of games. Even though the classes themselves are on spot, each one's gameplay isn't as deep or rewarding as the other's (with the Pilot and especially the Scientist suffering the most, as they have limited impact and almost no unique presence in the game). 
Class talents are also in certain need of rework, as some are completely must-have whereas others fall into the meh/useless category, resulting in practically no choice over which talents to level and when. Their number is also limited- class talents can be maxed out after just a couple of hours.

[b]Technical[/b]
Graphics are definitely not state-of-the-art. They certainly don't fail to convey the eeriness of space, but there's room for improvement, especially on characters and animations. 
Sound is decent. The soundtrack could be more ambient and trippy- I feel the current background music is rather blant but I guess that's personal taste. The sound effects are especially well-made and convincing, and there's at least one for every major event (warping, taking hull damage, being set on fire, being shot in the face by a space-robot-bandit etc.)
Performance was flawless on a system just below the recommended specs, and I was even able to run it decently on a dated laptop just above the minimum specs.
Bugs do occur once in a while, and they can sometimes force you to quit and reload, but that's rather rare (2 forced reloads in 14 hours).


[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
+Great potential
+Fun, unique concept
+Well implemented mechanics
+Obviously made with love and passion
-Graphics aren't really great
-Limited content
-Classes and talents need work
-Game wouldn't let us warp away and leave our bossy captain behind in a desolate desert planet

Overall, the game is already super fun to play with friends, especially if you're into sci-fi. If you don't mind the occasional bugs (of which there really aren't thaaat many), the slight class balance issues, the limited content, the rather high price, and can look past the non-realistic graphics, I recommend buying this game. Otherwise, you may want to wait a bit for some polishing to get done and some extra content to be added.

18046075.review:
Pulsar: Lost Colony is a cooperative 1-5 player starship simulator, where you can pick up quests, battle enemy ships, explore planets and engage in hostile ground fights, beam aboard other ships and take them over or sabatage it.

[h1]The Basics[/h1]

There are 5 roles available to choose from they are;
[list]
[*] Captain; Give orders to your crew, modify your ship and manage your credits
[*] Pilot; Fly the ship, collect scrap Align to warp nodes, evasive manouvering.
[*] Engineer; [b]Power Management[/b]; ensure the ship does not overheat, and when it does use coolant appropriatly
[*] Scientist; Infect enemy ships with deadly virus' that can help turn the fate of the battle whilst keeping your cybersecurity online.
[*]Weapons Specialist; In this role you'll be responsible for dealing the most damage to the enemy. You'll have use of the main turret right away which stock deals a ton of damage. You'll also help out on your ship to help repel invasions.
[/list]

[h1]Review[/h1]
I've been playing PULSAR since Alpha dropped and it has gone from strength to strength, I've met some good crew mates who have become good friends since. The game captures the feeling of being aboard a starship superbly.
Of course this game is even more fun when You and your crew start to roleplay. I've lost count of how many times i've been yelling orders to my crew desperately trying to outplay the enemy startships. In my total play time i've had nothing but fun and I would honstly reccomend this game to any space fan.

One of my fondest memories so far was being in a fight against one of the sector commanders, it was a very long fight our ship was no way at all prepared for it but we all agreed to go hard or go home. After an exhausting battle and an extremely close call (We had around 30 hull left) we basked in the new found glory that we were truly unstoppable (After all, we killed one of the hardest Enemies in the game). Thats when poo started to hit the fan. We figured it was best to navigate to the nearest repair depot which was only 4 Warp jumps away (Close amirite?). So off we went, "Engineer, prepare the warp core for activation" I said. "Helmsman, Align us to SE 42" I continued, barking orders. After which we left the battleground and was on our way travelling at warp speed along our journey. The first 3 stops were quiet, a planet to beam down to and explore, scavanged a few items and we were on our way. When we got to SE 17 they were there. Waiting. I quickly changed the alert code to defend the ship, but I was too late. All three enemy ships had started to fire, our shields taking massive strain, our engineer was trying his best to allocate power accordingly but in the end it didn't matter, we weren't going to win this one. I knew that, and I believe my crew did too. We were overheating at a great pace and we were all out of coolant. Only one thing left to do I thought. "If we're going down then we are going to take them with us." I ordered our Engineer to disengage the reactor safety switch so we could eject the reactor. We did just that and managed to take two of the bastards with us in the explosion that followed.

Of course no game is without its bugs but even the ones present here get hammered down very quickly thanks to Leafy Games' super quick hotfixes.

11/10 would try outsmart AI and blow up again

18045997.review:
The game is fairly light on hardware, but packs a lot more underneath. At the moment, the game has a few recycled textures which allows it to run fast. 

The ships at the moment are limited. However with the introduction of the Roland-class, we can see a potential for larger ships and perhaps hybrid AI/Human crew. Each ship has their own unique traits or abilities which allow for different styles of play. However the end game items overshadows these abilities which results in the same endgame play. Ship systems as of Beta 1 are moderately balanced however with AI controlled turrets, the main turret becomes less of a priority to man since the AI can hit it's target most of the time when you have a good pilot.

The ground combat at the moment is a good step in the right direction. Variable landscape that change how the player has to adapt. The new environmental suits allow you to travel to dangerous locations without harm and the weapons are based on a tried and true trade-off method (one shoots fast but weak, one shoots slow but fast, etc.). At the moment, the gameplay requires players to dodge gun fire or melee attacks. Requires every little tactical movement when shooting back so players can easily duck behind cover to protect themselves. Player customization is fairly fixed on implants and tattoos, but allow for colour changes. Otherwise the customization is vast on hairstyles, facial and colour options. 

Like to see more in the future from Leafy Games, but I would deem this a playable Early Access and recommendable to anyone who enjoyed Star Trek: Elite Force with a mix of Artemis Ship Simulator.


(Psst, my YouTube Channel if anyone wants a peak of all the things that have progressed in game: https://www.youtube.com/user/nawkcire)

18045181.review:
Pulsar, le FTL 3D multijoueurs Rogue-Like.

Un titre un peu barbare mais qui résume un jeu excellent.
Jouez en équipe et partez explorer la galaxie (générée aléatoirement), combattez des alien avec vos amis dans l'espace ou sur des planètes et pourquoi pas tenter de capturer un vaisseau hostile. Mais attention aux infectés qui se propagent à grande vitesse...

Chacun son rôle : Capitaine, Piote, Ingénieur, Scientifique, Tireur et 4 vaisseaux sont de la partie (pour le moment)

Esquiver un vaisseau ennemi pendant que votre scientifique tente de contrer une cyber-attaque, tandis que votre ingénieur lutte pour empêcher votre moteur de surchauffer alors que le Tireur vous dit qu'il manque de puissance pour faire face et que le capitaine donne l'ordre de s'enfuir de ce traquenard en chargeant le moteur d'hyper-espace, telle sera l'ambiance de ce jeu basé sur le jeu d'équipe.

L'histoire est sommaire pour le moment mais déjà quelques quêtes saurons vous tenir en haleine, bien que le coeur du jeu soit l'exploration libre et à long terme, comprendre d'ou viennent ces être destructeurs que sont les infectés et y survivre.

Evidemment jouable aussi en solo ou sans forcément avoir un équipage de 5 personnes maximum, l'IA ne sera là que si vraiment vous manquez de monde et ne remplacera pas un vrai joueur (pour l'instant peut-être).
La destruction de votre vaisseau signera la fin de la partie et si vous jouez en Ironman mode votre sauvegarde sera effacée et vous devrez alors tout recommencer.
Le jeu peut sembler ardu aux premiers abords mais la prise en main est assez intuitive pour s'y retrouver rapidement, d'autant que les vidéos tuto sauront vous guider dans un premier temps.
Le PVP n'est pas (encore?) présent dans le jeu, mais la possibilité d'avoir plusieurs vaisseaux est envisagée.

Ne vous fiez pas à l'esthétique épurée, l'hyper-réalisme n'est pas souvent synonyme de lisibilitée.
Gros point positif pour l'ambiance sonore qui vous ravira les tympans. Entendre le son du metal se tordre lorsque les moteurs chargent et le bruit sourd d'un impact sur la coque renforcent l'immersion déjà bien présente.

Les développeurs sont très actifs et mettent souvent à jour le jeu avec toujours plus de contenu, sont à l'écoute des suggestions sur le forum et réalisent souvent des votes pour intégrer le nouveau design d'une station, par exemple.

Avis aux amateurs de jeux d'exploration en équipe : si vous voyez une partie ou le vaisseau se nomme le TARDIS vous serez le bienvenue.

J'en fais souvent des live si ça vous intéresse http://www.twitch.tv/edgemiles

Sur ce, amusez-vous bien.
